Summary: criminal law. murder. evidence sufficient to sustain charges. deceased shot during robbery of 17 cellphones from store. first appellant linked through fingerprints to cellphone. appellants identified at parade. conviction for murder and associated charges in order. no misdirection in imposition of effective sentence of life and 21 years respectively.

Judges: Sethole AJ and NV Khumalo J
Summary: criminal law. corruption. contravention of s 3(a)(i)(aa) prevention and combating of corrupt activities act 12 of 2004. evidence sufficient to sustain charge. arresting police officer allegedly accepting r2000 bail money on behalf of suspect where case not enrolled and suspect released. probabilities favouring appellant and to be give benefit of doubt. conviction set aside on appeal.

Judges: De Klerk AJ and MM Jansen J
Summary: criminal law. evidence. of identification. assessment of. conviction for robbery with aggravating circumstances of vehicle, cash and other items. single witness. pointed out at identification parade. alibi defence. court on appeal satisfied witness had opportunity for dependable observation and no reason to falsely implicate appellant. requisite caution exercised by court a quo. appeal dismissed.

Judges: NB Tuchten J and DS Fourie J
Summary: criminal law. sentence. prescribed sentences. minimum sentence. imposition of in terms of criminal law amendment act 105 of 1997. 'substantial and compelling circumstances'. appellant strangled lover in fit of rage. possibility deceased had infected him with hiv virus. however, appellant remorseful and plead guilty to murder. chances of reoffending remote and excellent candidate for rehabilitation. substantial and compelling circumstances warranting deviation from statutory minimum of 15 years. sentence of 10 years appropriate. appeal dismissed.

Judges: TM Makgoka J and ALCM Lephoko AJ
Summary: criminal law. evidence. accomplice evidence. evaluation of. court failed to take into account unsatisfactory evidence of co.accused and its inherent improbabilities. magistrate committed material misdirection, which vitiates conviction. evidence of co.accused must be treated with caution as that of accomplice. conviction and sentence set aside.

Defendant: Nkosi 2014 JDR 1076 (GP) \'97 Now reported at 2014 (2) SACR 525 (GP)
Judges: ACM. Pieterse AJ and S Potterill J
Summary: criminal law. verdict. competent verdicts. charge of attempted rape in terms of s 3 of criminal law (sexual offences and related matters) amendment act 32 of 2007. all elements of sexual assault proven by evidence, and competent verdict on attempt to contravene s 3 of act 32 of 2007. appeal against sentence upheld, reduced to 5 years' imprisonment.

Judges: VT Matati AJ and EM Kubushi J
Summary: criminal law. sentence. prescribed minimum sentences. criminal law amendment act 105 of 1997. charge. rape of 7.year.old by uncle. charge formulated in terms of s 51(2) and not s 51(1) but legally represented and provisions explained. distinguished from s v ndlovu 2017 (2) sacr 305 (cc). no misdirection. appeal against imposition of life term dismissed.

Judges: LM Molopa-Sethosa J and VV Tlhapi J
Summary: criminal law. trial. irregularity. what constitutes. guilty plea to charge of trespassing in terms of s 1(1) of trespass act 6 of 1959. referred to regional court for sentencing in terms of s 114 (1)(b) instead s 116(1) of the criminal procedure act 51 of 1977 and defence not provided with opportunity to address on issue. also no evidence accused 2 entered complainant's property or building, rather that sat outside and watched. conviction for accused 2 not in accordance with justice and set aside, matter remitted to court a quo to sentence accused 1.

Judges: EM Kubushi J and PM Mabuse J
Summary: criminal law. plea. plea of guilty. convicted on charge of theft after questioning in terms of s 112(b). special review. questioning too cryptic and not clear whether admits all elements of offence. conviction and sentence set aside, matter remitted for retrial before another magistrate.

Judges: LI Vorster AJ and P Van Niekerk AJ
Summary: criminal law. murder. evidence sufficient to sustain charges. also rape (two counts), kidnapping and assault (two counts). no irregularity in reasoning of magistrate nor were the imposed sentences shockingly harsh. appeal dismissed.

Judges: S Potterill J and SS Mphahlele J
Summary: criminal law. bail. failure of accused on bail to appear at trial. trial court incorrectly holding   enquiries under s 170 instead of s 67a of criminal procedure act 51 of 1977. convictions and sentences reviewed and set aside.

Defendant: Nhlapho 2015 JDR 0870 (GP) \'97 Now reported at 2016 (1) SACR 489 (GP)
Judges: Jansen J and Bertelsmann J
Summary: criminal law. trial. assessors. absence of. no assessors appointed by court and accused not having requested court to proceed in absence of such. constituting gross irregularity enabling high court to interfere even before conviction. magistrates' court act 32 of 1944, s 93ter.

Judges: TM Makgoka J and TP Mudau AJ
Summary: criminal law. attempted murder. 2 counts against wife. domestic abuse. fired shots at wife who was hospitalised for 2 bullet wounds to the head. crashed into her with his car and then drove over her, breaking her limbs resulting in partial use of an arm. effective sentence of 12 years.

Judges: NV Khumalo J and Holland-Muter AJ
Summary: criminal law. evidence. circumstantial evidence. assessment of. appellant found in possession of stolen 50 us dollars and complainant's cellphone near scene minutes after armed robbery at bp garage \'97 firearm belonging to relative of appellant also found at scene. evidence overwhelming and conviction in order. failure to let sentences run concurrently, however, resulting in disproportionate sentence of 18 years. accordingly ordered to run concurrently reducing sentence to effective 15 years.

Judges: EM Kubushi J and MW Msimeki J
Summary: criminal law. sentence. error describing suspended portion. no need to refer back to magistrate. order made reflecting correct wording. r5000 fine with half suspended. failure to account for possession of goods reasonably suspected of being stolen. iron bars from roof.

Judges: VV Tlhapi J and K Makhafola J
Summary: criminal law. fundamental rights. right to a fair trial. right to legal representation. denial of such right would result in injustice. whether magistrate judiciously and in interests of justice properly exercised discretion to proceed with trial. accused afforded numerous opportunities to obtain legal representation. magistrate ordered to proceed with trial until finalized.

Judges: EM Kubushi J and PA Meyer J
Summary: criminal law. sentence. prescribed sentences. minimum sentences. imposition of in terms of criminal law amendment act 105 of 1997. 'substantial and compelling circumstances'. in imposing lengthy sentence it should not induce sense of shock. to be proportionate to offence committed. trial court erred materially in concluding no substantial and compelling circumstances. cumulatively, personal circumstances substantial and compelling circumstances to deviate. also plead guilty and showed remorse. appeal upheld, sentence replaced with 20 years' imprisonment.

Judges: NV Khumalo J, C Van Der Westhuizen AJ
Summary: criminal law. sentence. prescribed sentence. minimum sentences. imposition of in terms of criminal law amendment act 105 of 1997. 'substantial and compelling circumstances'. no physical injuries shall not constitute substantial and compelling. young victim attacked in public and dragged to soccer field where raped. appellant previous convictions for violence. no misdirection. appeal dismissed.

Judges: E Jordaan J
Summary: criminal law. murder. evidence sufficient to sustain charges. deceased shot and killed during home invasion and vehicles taken. accused acquitted in terms of s 174 of criminal procedure act 51 of 1977. accused 1 and 2 pointed out at identification parade, accused 1 identified as seller of deceased's vehicle and accused 2 making confession. neither accused credible witnesses. sufficient evidence to found convictions for both accused on housebreaking with intent to rob, robbery with aggravating circumstances and murder.

Judges: SA Thobane AJ and N Kollapen J
Summary: criminal law. evidence. adequacy of proof. onus of proof on state. despite failure to critically evaluate evidence as to identity, identity established by 2 witnesses. identity established beyond reasonable doubt. conviction stands, sentences set aside and reduced as per order.

Judges: RG Tolmay J, CP Rabie J and MF Legodi J
Summary: criminal law. murder. sentence. prescribed sentence in terms of s 51(2) of criminal law amendment act 105 of 1997. court misdirected in finding life imprisonment prescribed minimum sentence. not premeditated murder \'96 applicable sentence 15 years' imprisonment. court also placed too much emphasis on previous convictions and too little consideration on lack of sobriety. appeal succeeds, sentence reduced to 12 years' imprisonment.

Judges: HJ Fabricius J and AJ Bam J
Summary: criminal law. trial. presiding officer. unavailability of to continue with trial. magistrate continuously unavailable due to ill.health. interests of justice to set aside and recommence afresh.

Judges: FG Preller J and HJ Fabricius J
Summary: criminal law. review. high court has jurisdiction to review. even though matter does not fall with normal review powers, court should exercise inherent jurisdiction to ensure justice is done. proceedings set aside and matter to start de novo\'97superior courts act 10 of 2013, s 21(1)(b).

Judges: NB Tuchten J and EM Kubushi J
Summary: criminal law. housebreaking. housebreaking with intent to rob and robbery. sentence. not shocking and disproportionate. previous convictions for theft and assault. accused on parole when committed current offence. looting of shops become prevalent and described as disease. appeal dismissed.

Judges: N Ranchod J, D Mlambo J and K Makhafola J
Summary: criminal law. sentence. minimum sentencing provisions. no record of accused being made aware that these would apply to their charges of robbery with aggravating circumstances. case law examined on this topic. substantial and compelling circumstances not found on appeal.

Judges: JS Strydom AJ and DS Molefe J
Summary: criminal law. rape. 3 times. short breaks between rapes. disputed whether ejaculated each time. not a requirement. multiple rapes accepted. life sentence.

Judges: TS Madima AJ and Prinsloo J
Summary: criminal law. evidence. witnesses. credibility. single child witness. repeated rape of 12.year.old female cousin. supported by medial evidence. conviction in order. first offender, aged 47 and unmarried. no remorse. no serious physical injuries. no misdirection in imposition of life imprisonment.

Judges: Mia AJ
Summary: criminal law. theft. evidence sufficient to sustain charge. copper cable to value of r1000. security guards apprehending appellant digging hole where cables removed. contention that unwittingly assisting client not credible. conviction confirmed.

Judges: ALCM Lephoko AJ and G Webster J
Summary: criminal law. robbery. aggravating circumstances. appeals against convictions dismissed. appeals against sentences also dismissed. accused used firearms in a well.planned robbery of a shop. second appellant was a police officer at time of offence. abuse of trust aggravating and rightly given 3 extra years for a sentence of 18 years.

Judges: NF De Jager AJ
Summary: criminal law. evidence. rape conviction. complainant asleep and drunk when alleged rape took place. complainant's evidence not reliable. insufficient further evidence to sustain conviction. conviction set aside.

Judges: LM Molopa-Sethosa J, MJ Teffo J and D Dosio AJ
Summary: criminal law. sentence. imposition of. factors to be taken into account. despite severe aggravation, mercy displayed in recognising consecutive imposition of applicable minimum would cumulatively lead to sentence of 60 years' imprisonment. accordingly made concurrency orders resulting in effective sentence of 35 years imprisonment. no misdirection or disproportionality. appeal dismissed.

Judges: Madima AJ
Summary: criminal law. arms and ammunition. unlawful possession of firearm in contravention of s 3 of firearms control act 60 of 2000. sentence. appeal against conviction and sentence of 15 years. lack of knowledge that firearm is semi.automatic not vitiating elements of crime of possession of firearm. trial court committed irregularity by not alerting appellant of prescribed sentences.

Judges: E Bertelsmann J and W Hughes J
Summary: criminal law. review. special review. number of irregularities resulting in unfair trial. conviction and sentence set aside, accused to be released immediately.

Judges: Strauss AJ and TJ Raulinga J
Summary: criminal law. theft. sentence. too much emphasis placed on prevalence of theft in jurisdiction. too little emphasis on fact that all goods returned. plead guilty, relatively young first offenders. appeal upheld, sentenced to 3 years' imprisonment, portion suspended conditionally.

Judges: RG Tolmay J and C Pretorius J
Summary: criminal law. trial. record. lost, destroyed or incomplete. record submitted for review incomplete on 2 occasions. magistrate submitting that transcription and filing problems. court finding that magistrate ought to have transcribed record, however, no irregularity re conviction as accused pleaded guilty to theft of ipad. relatively young first offender with young child and sentence of 12 months unduly harsh. altered to fine of r2000 or 6 months' imprisonment wholly suspended.

Judges: RG Tolmay J and C Pretorius J
Summary: criminal law. theft. sentence. unemployed 28.year.old male, married with small children, pleading guilty. previous convictions more than 7 years before and should have play limited role. suspended sentence more appropriate. sentence of 24 months imprisonment (half suspended) reduced to 8 months wholly suspended on appeal.

Judges: TJ Raulinga J and JW Louw J
Summary: criminal law. sentence. imposition of. factors to be taken into account. youth is factor court has to consider seriously. necessary to guard against imposing uniform sentences that did not distinguish between facts of different cases and person circumstances of appellant. court did not exercise discretion correctly. appeal upheld, sentence of 3 years imprisonment set aside, accused to pay r4000 fine, failing which 6 months' imprisonment.

Judges: TJ Raulinga J, RG Tolmay J and NV Khumalo J
Summary: criminal law. murder. evidence sufficient to sustain charges. deceased shot during armed robbery. credible witnesses placing appellants on scene. in possession of firearm linked to killing. correctly convicted of murder and associated charges. no misdirection in effective sentence of 20 years' imprisonment.

Judges: NB Tuchten J, N Ranchod J and EM Kubushi J
Summary: criminal law. murder, attempted murder and other charges. evidence sufficient to support charges. contract killing. single witness who was also accomplice. insufficient corroboration to reduce risk of conviction. on appeal, conviction and sentence overturned.

Judges: Jansen J and Moseamo J
Summary: criminal law. rape. daughter age 6. mother inducing child to accuse friend of father. evidence of rape victims who are dependant and emotionally attached to rapist. on further questioning, daughter revealing mother's instructions and confirming father as rapist. father age 64 at sentencing and of low iq as well as being in poor health. 15 years for the rape. 8 years for anal rape prior to new act. 4 years for oral sex.

Judges: De Vos J and Mavundla J
Summary: criminal law. theft. sentence. accused convicted of theft of explosives and explosive equipment. direct imprisonment not misdirection. personal circumstances given serious consideration, weighed up against seriousness of offence. accused in position of trust when stole explosives. also manner in which handled and would have sold. appeal dismissed.

Judges: CJ van der Westhuizen AJ and NV Khumalo J
Summary: criminal law. evidence. of identification. no flaws as alleged in identification parade. complainant traumatised by event yet was able to correctly identify appellant. sentence increased on appeal to 15 years' imprisonment. appeal against conviction dismissed.

Judges: HJ Fabricius J and DS Fourie J
Summary: criminal law. sentence. correction of. sentence not reflecting magistrate's intention to impose sentence with deterrent effect. suggested substitute sentence imposed on special review.

Judges: WRC Prinsloo J and W Hughes J
Summary: criminal law. theft. unlawful possession of stolen goods. contravention of general amendment act 62 of 1955. requisites. must be found to be in possession and not after ceases to be in possession. appeal upheld, conviction set aside.

Judges: MJ Mushasha AJ and NB Tuchten
Summary: criminal law. sentence. prescribed sentences. minimum sentences. imposition of in terms of criminal law amendment act 105 of 1997. 'substantial and compelling circumstances'. court required to impose sentence that prescribed unless substantial and compelling circumstances. all circumstances in casu do not constitute warranting departure from minimum of 15 years' imprisonment. appeal dismissed.

Judges: TP Mudau AJ and Fabricius J
Summary: criminal law. evidence. witnesses. calling, examination and refutation of. the oath. administering of. to juvenile witness. at age 18 at time of giving testimony cannot be argued young child not understanding nature and import of oath or affirmation. evidence of complainant properly admitted. appeal dismissed.

Judges: MJ Mosopa AJ and CP Rabie J
Summary: criminal law. rape. evidence to sustain charge. single, child witness of 13 (11 at time of incident) not treated with necessary caution \'97 material contradiction in evidence. probation officer informed by complainant, when visiting to assess impact of rape, that was never raped by appellant. evidence not sufficient to secure conviction. convictions and effective life sentence set aside.

Judges: MC De Klerk AJ and TJ Raulinga J
Summary: criminal law. rape. 2 woman accosted by 5 men at night. 1 victim raped by 3 men. other woman menstruating so forced to perform oral sex. also robbed. common purpose discussed as well as youth of perpetrators and prior convictions, whether affecting sentences.

Judges: TP Mudau AJ and Janse Van Niewenhuizen J
Summary: criminal law. evidence. witnesses. children. when complainants and witnesses in sexual.offence cases. evidence of 2 child complainants corroborated each other materially. rejected appeallant's evidence as not reasonably possibly true. appeal dismissed.

Judges: SAM Baqwa J and EM Kubushi J
Summary: criminal law. rape. proof of. complainant contending gassed by appellant, a previous lover, in his vehicle. naked when regained consciousness although no recollection of being raped. issues to be determined included (1) whether in fact raped; and (2) identity of rapist. versions mutually destructive. court a quo not applying requisite standard of proof inferring guilt on part of appellant. conviction for rape set aside.

Judges: N Janse Van Nieuwenhuizen J and DT Skosana AJ
Summary: criminal law. murder. proof of. murder of girlfriend at her residence. appellant admitting to being present earlier in evening but denying charge. version substantiated by witness. probabilities in favour of appellant not considered by court a quo. case not proved beyond a reasonable doubt. conviction set aside on appeal.

Judges: Moloto AJ and N Janse Van Nieuwenhuizen J
Summary: criminal law. rape. life sentence applying when victim raped more than once. victim abducted from street and detained overnight. threatened with firearm. intervention by victims' friends and accused's own friend to no avail. raped 4 times. 3 times vaginal and once anal. life sentence imposed by regional court. high court on appeal finding the sentence disturbingly inappropriate and reducing to 20 years. appellant age 24 and first offender.

Judges: VRSN Nkosi AJ and W Msimeki J
Summary: criminal law. sentence. prescribed sentences. imposition of in terms of criminal law amendment act 105 of 1997. 'substantial and compelling circumstances'. court misdirected itself in not finding following factors cumulatively amounted to substantial and compelling circumstances \'96 appellant first offender, in custody for almost 2 years and record not reflect postponements due to any fault of appellant,\'97 appeal upheld, life sentence set aside, substituted with 22 years' imprisonment.

Judges: NV Khumalo J and DS Fourie J
Summary: criminal law. rape. elements of. absence of consent. child under age of 12 cannot in terms of act consent to sexual intercourse. court observed complainant cannot physically be mistaken for 16 year old. not possible that appellant could have been deceived to think complainant 16 years old and consent to sexual intercourse. appellant knowingly had sexual intercourse with 11.year.old without consent. appeals dismissed.

Judges: PM Mabuse J (WRC Prinsloo J and LM Molopa-Sethosa J concurring)
Summary: criminal law. sentence. appropriateness of sentences of imprisonment cumulatively far in excess of 25 years (so.called methuselah sentence). effective 50 years imprisonment imposed for multiple crimes including attempted murder, aggravated robbery and housebreaking with intent to rob and aggravated robbery. first offender, 22 years old, showing no remorse and motivated by greed. sentence effectively depriving appellant of any chance of rehabilitation. misdirection in emphasising interests of community at expense of personal circumstances. effective term reduced to 30 years.

Judges: LM Montsho AJ (Maumela J concurring)
Summary: criminal law. rape. sentence. accused aged 71 at time of rape. appealing 20 year sentence. hit victim age 19 with fist. 3 previous rape convictions where he violated his parole conditions. appeal dismissed.

Judges: DP de Villiers AJ and N Janse van Nieuwenhuizen J
Summary: criminal law. robbery. aggravating circumstances. evidence sufficient to sustain charge. robbery of vehicle. application of doctrine of recent possession. conviction in order. appellant 31 years old with previous convictions. no evidence led on mitigation. no grounds for interference in imposition of prescribed minimum sentence of 15 years' imprisonment. appeal dismissed.

Judges: TM Makgoka J and LM Molopa-Sethosa J
Summary: criminal law. sentence. imposition of. factors to be taken into account. imposition of minimum sentence for robbery with aggravating circumstances in terms of s 51 of criminal law amendment act 105 of 1997. personal circumstances of appellants relevant in considering sentence. lower courts simply recite without considering impact on sentence. magistrate did not consider poor socio.economic backgrounds of appellants. imbalanced consideration. these factors cumulatively constituting substantial and compelling circumstances. sentence on counts 2 and 3 reduced to 10 years' imprisonment and ordered to run concurrently.

Defendant: Mthethwa 2014 JDR 1436 (GP) \'97 Now reported at 2015 (1) SACR 609 (GP)
Judges: TM Makgoka J and R Tolmay J
Summary: criminal law. rape. elements of. penetration. proof of. medical examination revealed signs of repeated penetration, but could not tell if signs of fresh penetration. state failed to prove was penetrated on date of alleged offence. issue not whether penetrated before, but whether on date of alleged offence. complainant's evidence as single witness was also poor and lacked coherence. appeal upheld, conviction and sentence set aside.

Judges: TM Makgoka J and PD Moseamo AJ
Summary: criminal law. sentence. prescribed sentences. minimum sentence. imposition of in terms of criminal law amendment act 105 of 1997. charge.sheet. error in. incorrect reference to s 51 (2) of the act instead of s 51(1), which decrees imprisonment for life. sentencing court not precluded from imposing life sentence solely on basis charge sheet erroneously refers to incorrect section. no unfairness in trial. vigilant examination of facts no prejudice is discernible due to error. none alleged. appeal dismissed.

Judges: HJ Fabricius J and AJ Bam J
Summary: criminal law. trial. irregularity. plea of guilty to charge of theft in terms of s 112(1)(a). sentence imposed of imprisonment without option of fine incompetent. conviction set aside on special review and matter remitted to magistrate for proper sentence.

Judges: N Janse Van Nieuwenhuizen J and TP Mudau AJ
Summary: criminal law. evidence. assessment of. identification. complainant kidnapped and raped by appellant in his house. second incident few months later, accosted her, took to same house and raped again. complainant specifically pointed out appellant's house and room where raped. also identified appellant. highly unlikely would know exactly where appellant lived if not taken there to be raped. identity established beyond a doubt.

Judges: TJ Raulinga J and RG Tolmay J
Summary: criminal law. trial. irregularity in. what constitutes. legal representative for accused nos 1 and 2 not admitted as attorney. effect on proceedings unascertainable. set aside and remitted to start de novo.

Judges: LM Molopa-Sethosa J, FHD Van Oosten J and S Potterill J
Summary: criminal law. appeal. against sentence. powers of court on appeal. sentencing falling primarily within discretion of trial court. court entitled to interfere if sentence disturbingly inappropriate, so totally out of proportion to magnitude of offence, or sufficiently disparate, or vitiated by misdirections showing that trial court exercised discretion unreasonably. sentence imposed reflect gravity of crimes, not disproportionate. effective sentence appropriate, appeal dismissed, save sentence on count 4 substituted with period of 8 years' imprisonment.

Judges: TA Maumela J, Ranchod J and Van der Westhuizen AJ
Summary: criminal law. murder. evidence sufficient to sustain charge. appellant firing multiple shots at and killing wife. both saps members, separated and appellant subject to protection order under domestic violence act 116 of 1998. eye witnesses and ballistic evidence. claim of private defence against deceased and 2 male friends correctly rejected. conviction in order. first offender, 41 years of age and lost employment as result of incident. committed in full view their 2.year.old child. no misdirection in imposition of 18 years, a sentence exceeding prescribed minimum.

Judges: De Vos J and Molefe J
Summary: criminal law. review. special review in terms of s 304(4) of criminal procedure act 51 of 1977. in what case. application brought, before accused convicted and sentenced, for matter to be stopped and heard de novo before another magistrate. should have been brought in terms of provisions of rule 53. struck from roll.

Judges: JW Louw J and MW Msimeki J
Summary: criminal law. sexual offences. criminal law (sexual offences and related matters) amendment act 32 of 2007. appellant charged with rape as contemplated in s 3 of sexual offences act. erroneously convicted of indecent assault as common law crimes of rape and indecent assault repealed by s68(1)(b). provision made for competent verdicts in s261 of criminal procedure act 51 of 1977, should evidence not prove rape. evidence in casu did not prove any of competent verdicts. conviction and sentence on count 2 set aside. appeal against conviction and sentence on count 1 set aside.

Defendant: Motsepe (Freedom of Expression Amicus Curiae) 2014 JDR 2706 (GP) \'97 Now reported at 2015 (5) SA 126 (GP); 2015 (2) SACR 125 (GP)
Judges: DS Molefe J and N Janse van Nieuwenhuizen J
Summary: criminal law. defamation. media. journalist appealing conviction of defamation. published story defamatory of magistrate. based on incorrect facts which journalist believed to be true. lacking intention. appeal succeeding. various amici seeking to have common law crime of defamation declared unconstitutional in regard to the media. not succeeding.

Judges: C Pretorius J, MW Msimeki J and NB Tuchten J
Summary: criminal law. sentence. prescribed sentences. minimum sentence. imposition of in terms of criminal law amendment act 105 of 1997. court a quo erred in imposing sentence of 30 years', no indication or reasons for double prescribed sentence in judgment. appears no consideration given to substantial and compelling circumstances. therefore sentence should be set aside and replaced with minimum of 15 years' imprisonment.

Judges: Bosman AJH and AML Phatudi J
Summary: criminal law. assault. assault with intent to do grievous bodily harm. what constitutes. accused beat complainant with waist belt, leaving 'tram.lines' across back of thighs. no serious injuries inflicted, thus not convinced all elements of offence present. magistrate misdirection himself in such finding. conviction inappropriate and set aside. matter to start de novo and plea of not guilty to be entered.

Judges: RG Tolmay J and C Pretorius J
Summary: criminal law. drugs offences. dagga. possession of. conviction. amended as typographical error which should be rectified. accused guilty of possession of dagga of 5,67kg of dagga.

Judges: CJ Collis J (L Molopa-Sethosa J concurring)
Summary: criminal law. murder. sentence. appellant and others stabbed deceased (who was clearly intoxicate) multiple times. after the group moved on, appellant and another returned to stab deceased again. first offender aged 19. insufficient emphasis on youthfulness. sentence reduced from 15 to 10 years.

Judges: N Davis AJ, D Rossouw AJ and DS Molefe J
Summary: criminal law. criminal law. murder. mens rea. common purpose. no evidence to indicate appellants had any other intention than to remove muti from where buried. also no evidence of having weapons or having assaulted deceased. no support for finding of requisite mens rea or having made common purpose with crowd who had in fact done killings. state has not proven case beyond reasonable doubt. convictions and sentences set aside.

Judges: MB Mokoena J and TP Mudau J
Summary: criminal law. evidence. of identification. theft of cattle to value of r1000 000. seen herding cattle. identification sound. branded cattle recently stolen, and, in absence of explanation for possession of such, only reasonable inference was that appellants responsible for theft. convictions confirmed.

Judges: JJ Strijdom AJ and PM Mabuse J
Summary: criminal law. failure to appear. amount of fine and alternative prison sentence not in order. sentence imposed by magistrate's court set aside and changed to r1000 or 3 months' imprisonment.

Judges: AC Basson J and M Senyatsi AJ
Summary: criminal law. robbery. aggravating circumstances. sentence. also unlawful possession of firearms and ammunition. firearm carried during robbery \'97 appellant aged 33 and married with children. no grounds for interference in sentences of 15 years for aggravated robbery and 3 years for firearm offences, to run concurrently.

Judges: AC Basson J, M Mavundla J and N Janse Van Nieuwenhuizen J
Summary: criminal law. evidence. of identification. dock identification. carries little weight on own. danger to dock identification evidence that complainant will point out offender simply because sees offender in dock. other than dock evidence no independent evidence links appellant no 3 to 3 charges. conviction and sentence set aside for appellant no 3.

Judges: EM Kubushi J and AC Basson J
Summary: criminal law. appeal. against sentence. power of court on appeal to interfere with sentence. 1 or more of the accepted grounds justifying interference on appeal must exist. whether sentence induces sense of shock. sentence in this instance appropriate. balanced consideration of all factors. appeal dismissed.

Judges: EK Tsatsi AJ and EM Kubushi J
Summary: criminal law. trespass. what constitutes. contravention of s 1(1) of trespass act 6 of 1959. whether or not appellant committed an offense in terms of act. charge cannot succeed unless mens rea. appellant's version did not have necessary intention. appeal upheld, conviction and sentence set aside.

Judges: TJ Raulinga J and S Strauss AJ
Summary: criminal law. sentence. prescribed sentences. imposition of in terms of criminal law amendment act 105 of 1997. 'substantial and compelling circumstances'. shot and killed lover's daughter in a fit of revenge, thinking it was lover. infected appellant with hiv virus and openly engaged in sexual intercourse with other men. appellant first offender, plead guilty and remorseful. sentence imposed to be proportional to offences committed. eligible for rehabilitation. appeal upheld, sentence on count 1 reduced to 20 years' imprisonment.

Judges: AC Basson J and W Hughes J
Summary: criminal law. evidence. of identification. single accomplice witness. convicted on charge of robbery with aggravating circumstances \'97 state conceding evidence riddled with inconsistencies, contradictions and improbabilities. evidence not in compliance with legal safeguards set for such witnesses. convictions set aside.

Judges: Jansen J and Molefe J
Summary: criminal law. trial. discharge of accused at close of state case. on counts of corruption and contravening poca. state contending wrong test for acquittal applied. test discussed. court concluding magistrate clearly applied test and correctly decided only acquittal could follow given mishmash of evidence adduced. criminal procedure act 51 of 1977, s 174.

Judges: MV Semenya AJ and N Janse Van Nieuwenhuizen J
Summary: criminal law. robbery aggravating. appeal against conviction and sentence. no reason to interfere with conviction or sentence of 10 years. robbed 2 women in a car of their possessions. firearm used to threaten. punched driver. appeals dismissed.

Judges: W Hughes J and TP Mudau AJ
Summary: criminal law. sentence. prescribed sentence. minimum sentences. imposition of in terms of criminal law amendment act 105 of 1997. 'substantial and compelling circumstances'. none submitted in mitigation of sentence. if none submitted starting point is minimum sentence as prescribed. in circumstances appeal fails.

Judges: E Bertelsmann J and TJ Raulinga J
Summary: criminal law. review. special review in terms of s 304(4) of criminal procedure act 51 of 1977\'97 in what cases. possibility of bias on part of magistrate as had resided over bail hearing and trial, had knowledge of previous convictions at trial stage. also district court had no further jurisdiction to try matter referred to regional court. proceedings reviewed and set aside.

Judges: NM Mavundla J and MW Msimeki J
Summary: criminal law. trial. presiding officer. unavailability of to continue with trial. due to death of presiding magistrate. proceedings were a nullity and had to commence de novo before another magistrate.

Judges: Makume J and Maluleke AJ
Summary: criminal law. prescribed minimum sentences. criminal law amendment act 105 of 1997. substantial and compelling circumstances. time spent in custody. court a quo over emphasised the seriousness of the crime and under emphasised personal circumstances of accused. appeal upheld, substituted with 13 years' imprisonment.

Judges: NB Tuchten J and EM Kubushi J
Summary: criminal law. evidence. assessment of. identification. scene sufficiently illuminated to enable identification. appellant known to complainant and her brother who identified appellant independently. further corroboration in fingerprints of appellant at scene and evidence of state witness. appellant's version falls to be rejected as not reasonably possibly true. appeal dismissed.

Judges: AJ Bam J and ML Molopa-Sethosa J
Summary: criminal law. evidence. assessment of. state's evidence accepted over appellant's. present during 2 incidents of rape, accessory to. appellant's version improbable. appeal dismissed.

Judges: D S Fourie J and HJ Fabricius J
Summary: criminal law. plea. plea of guilty. section 112(2) statement in terms of criminal procedure act 51 of 1977 not reflecting factual basis upon which based or that prosecutor accepted said plea. conviction and sentence set aside and matter remitted to magistrate to comply with provisions of s 113 of act.

Judges: TD Vilakazi AJ and CP Rabie J
Summary: criminal law. evidence. witnesses. credibility. single witness. complainant version more plausible than appellant. witnesses corroborated complainant's version of being dragged and removed from her company. conviction confirmed.

Judges: SP Mothle J and EM Molahlehi AJ and N Davis AJ
Summary: criminal law. confession. admissibility of. murder charge. incriminating warning statement rejected as involuntary but incriminating pointing.out admitted. doubts on conspectus of evidence as to voluntariness of pointing.out. only evidence linking to offence. conviction and sentence set aside.

Judges: S Potterill J and SA Thobane AJ
Summary: criminal law. evidence. assessment of. identification. complainant knew appellant for many years and also saw his face clearly in street light. appellant offered to chaperone home from tavern, assaulted and raped thereafter. dna evidence corroborates version of complainant. court a quo entitled to impose life sentence. appeals dismissed.

Judges: L Vuma AJ and N Janse Van Nieuwenhuizen J
Summary: criminal law. rape. evidence sufficient to sustain charges. 2 6.year.old complainants. versions contradictory and mutually destructive in material respects. allegations not proved beyond reasonable doubt. appeal upheld and conviction and sentence set aside.

Judges: MM Jansen J and De Klerk AJ
Summary: criminal law. evidence. adequacy of proof. identification. complainant attacked in own home and robbed of cellphone and money. single witness. supported by circumstantial evidence. numerous improbabilities contradictions in appellant's version. conviction confirmed. sentence. twenty.year.old male with previous convictions. no pre.sentencing report and manner in which justice system failed him as child justifying departure from minimum sentencing. sentence altered to 8 years on count 1 and 3 years on count 2, to run concurrently with 1.

Judges: TM Makgoka J and MJ Teffo J
Summary: criminal law. admission of guilt. accused paying admission of guilt fine unaware that would acquire criminal record. police threatened accused to pay and failed to inform of consequences should admission of guilt be paid. failure to do so will result in conviction being set aside. conviction set aside, admission of guilt fine set aside and monies to be refunded.

Judges: N Janse Van Nieuwenhuizen J and N Davis AJ
Summary: criminal law. evidence. identification. complainant forced into veld, raped and robbed of cash, cards and cellphone \'97 co.perpetrator linked through dna evidence. appellant and co.perpetrator identified at id parade. sufficient time to make reliable identification. conviction in order and appeal dismissed.

Judges: Weiner J and SS Madiba AJ
Summary: criminal law. murder. sentence. appellant and co.accused shot and killed elderly deceased during housebreaking. first offender who pleaded guilty. sentence reduced from 20 years' imprisonment to 15 years.

Judges: AP Ledwaba DJP and Thobane AJ
Summary: criminal law. sentence. factors to be taken into account. accused unable to pay fine, requested postponed sentence. trial court of view accused obsessed with complainant and held direct imprisonment appropriate. sentence harsh and induces sense of shock. appropriate sentence 3 months, 1 month to be suspended.

Judges: CP Rabie J, MF Legodi J and RG Tolmay J
Summary: criminal law. sentence. factors to be taken into account. actions of complainant in defending off appellant to some degree diminish moral responsibility of deed. complainant wrestled with appellant causing shot to go off striking deceased. furthermore appellant intoxicated at time. in conjunction first offender, in custody for 1 year 4 months constitute substantial and compelling circumstances.

Judges: N Janse Van Nieuwenhuizen J and MG Phatudi AJ
Summary: criminal law. evidence. expert evidence. dna analysis. chain of evidence established. section 212 certificate accepted into evidence. appellant correctly convicted, appeal falls to be set aside.

Judges: Strauss S AJ, Molefe J and Fabricius J
Summary: criminal law. evidence. circumstantial evidence. assessment of. inferential reasoning. dna evidence corroborating circumstantial evidence. cigarette butts and beer cans containing dna of both accused close to where dead body was found. not likely anyone driving alongside road would throw these items into mealie field where body found. appeal dismissed.

Judges: MV Semenya AJ and LM Molopa-Sethosa J
Summary: criminal law. evidence. witnesses. credibility of. contradictions per se do not lead to rejection of witness' evidence. not every mistake made by witness affects credibility. have to make an evaluation, look at nature of contradictions, number and importance, and bearing on witness evidence. appeal dismissed.

Judges: N Kollapen J and NV Khumalo J
Summary: criminal law. trial. irregularity in. what constitutes. irregularity of such nature does not preclude consideration of merits of case. magistrate had resided over bail application where previous convictions had been disclosed. magistrate should have recused himself. cumulative effect of irregularities has effect of rendering trial unfair. conviction set aside, matter referred back to office national director of public prosecutions.

Judges: MW Msimeki J and AML Phatudi J
Summary: criminal law. review. special review in terms of s 304(4) of criminal procedure act 51 of 1977. accused statement in terms of s 112(2) of the cpa evinces no culpability. was incumbent on presiding magistrate to have altered plea of guilty to 1 of not guilty. conviction and sentence thus improper. conviction and sentence set aside, matter remitted to presiding magistrate to record plea of not guilty and proceed with trial.

Judges: NB Tuchten J and DS Fourie J
Summary: criminal law. rape. attempted rape. what constitutes. assault on woman with intent to rape her. woman dying as a result of assault. attempted rape proved. inference that deceased was alive when body violated is not only reasonable inference. same with regards to robbery charge. state failed to prove appellant used violence or threat of to deprive deceased of cellphone. other inference that appellant formed intention to steal after deceased dead. rape conviction altered to attempted rape and robbery to theft. sentences altered accordingly.

Defendant: Mokgara 2014 JDR 2200 (GP) \'97 Now reported at 2015 (1) SACR 634 (GP)
Judges: Mothel J, Teffo J and De Vos J
Summary: criminal law. sentence. prescribed sentences. minimum sentence. imposition of in terms of criminal law amendment act 105 of 1997. not sufficient information before court regarding personal circumstances of appellant to make an informed decision on sentence. duty on presiding officer to ask pertinent questions and request probation officer report and/or victim impact report. appellant subjected to risk no substantial and compelling circumstances based on inadequate or insufficient evidence. accordingly sentence set aside, referred back to magistrate to consider afresh.

Judges: Fabricius J and Hughes J and Makhubele AJ
Summary: criminal law. murder. sentence. attempted murder, housebreaking with intent to commit robbery and robbery, theft and unlawful possession of firearm and ammunition. cumulative sentence of 68 and 64 years, respectively, imposed on appellants. misdirection in imposing sentence designed to 'lock the door and throw away the key'. no explanation advanced for deviating from mandatory life term on murder count. sentence altered from 30 years to prescribed life term, sentences on other counts to run concurrently.

Judges: TA Maumela J and SB Mngadi AJ
Summary: criminal law. murder. sentence. appellant caught deceased breaking into his property and exceeded limits of private defence when he struck deceased repeatedly with panga. first offender aged 51. no grounds for interference in sentence, court a quo already imposing less than prescribed minimum.

Judges: LM Molopa-Sethosa J, EM Kubushi J and P Van Der Byl AJ
Summary: criminal law. evidence. adequacy of proof. onus of proof on state. whether version of accused to be rejected. totality of evidence it is not inconceivable that accused version is truth. bearing in mind appellant's brother is lawful owner of firearm in issue. brother also confirmed version of appellant. appeal upheld, conviction set aside.

Judges: C Pretorius J, NV Khumalo J and D Nair AJ
Summary: criminal law. general principles of liability. common purpose. dissociation from common purpose. appellant could not have foreseen brutal attack and torture on occupants. accused 3 and 4 went beyond what was necessary to subdue. appellant knew there was to be robbery and fact somebody might get hurt. brutal attack and torture. degree of participation in robbery and assaults much less than co.accused. substantial and compelling circumstance that last conviction was 12 years' prior. appeal upheld, sentences reduced as per order.

Judges: NB Tuchten J and V Tlhapi J
Summary: criminal law. rape. evidence to sustain charge. waylaid by gang of young men on way home from tavern, stabbed, dragged into pit toilet, stripped, head forced into toilet bowl and raped repeatedly. dna link to second third and fourth appellants. corroboration by medical evidence. independent witness placing on scene, identification of first appellant by complainant\'97 convictions in order. no remorse. particularly dreadful crime. treated as less than human. planning to kill complainant but thwarted by witness who alerted the police. each had previous convictions. life terms for each confirmed.

Judges: MF Legodi J, WRC Prinsloo J and TJ Raulinga J
Summary: criminal law. sentence. murder and attempted murder. gang feud. execution in court building. multiple shots into body of deceased. planned. 40 years for murder. 10 years for attempted murder.

Judges: C Pretorius J, MW Msimeki J and NB Tuchten J
Summary: criminal law. sentence. prescribed sentences. minimum sentence. imposition of in terms of criminal law amendment act 105 of 1997. indictment. lacked detail which would bring in ambit of minimum sentencing regime. appellant must be advised of fact that ultimate sentence of life imprisonment could be imposed due to fact that he and another person raped complainant to be applied and implications and consequences thereof. sentence of life imprisonment set aside, replaced with 18 years' imprisonment.

Judges: Khami Makhafola J and VV Tlhapi J
Summary: criminal law. review. special review. accused represented by legal representative with no right of appearance. conduct inexcusable. impacts on coreness of justness and fairness of trial. fatal irregularity vitiates trial. convictions and sentences set aside, trial to start de novo.

Judges: Kubushi J
Summary: criminal law. evidence. section 204 witness. criminal procedure act 51 of 1977. prosecution applying for witness to be warned after he had been asked some questions. he did not implicate himself or the accused in these questions. witness can be warned at any time before the incriminating questions have been asked.

Judges: NB Tuchten J and M Madima AJ
Summary: criminal law. rape. sentence. victim age 13. accused age 25 and has 2 children. was on parole for previous rape conviction when he raped again. broke into home, threatened girl with knife, raped her and then stole her possessions. life sentence confirmed on appeal.

Judges: HK Kooverjie AJ and AA Louw J
Summary: criminal law. rape. sentence. grievous bodily harm. intent to seriously injure. not found where object like nail clippers used to scratch victim. purpose to subdue. life imprisonment reduced to 14 years.

Judges: WRC Prinsloo J, W Hughes J and C Cambanis AJ
Summary: criminal law. evidence. circumstantial evidence. assessment of. inference not consistent with proven facts. cannot exclude other reasonable inferences. appeal upheld, conviction and sentence set aside.

Judges: SAM Baqwa J and P Phahlane AJ
Summary: criminal law. sentence. concurrence of sentences. entered residence of victims and stabbed female complainant and male deceased with knife and iron bar, respectively. sentenced to 6 months' imprisonment for assault gbh and 15 years for murder. sentences appropriate, however, since linked so closely in time and locality court a quo ought to have ordered that run concurrently. sentence altered accordingly.

Defendant: Mnguni 2014 JDR 1524 (GP) \'97 Now reported at 2014 (2) SACR 595 (GP)
Judges: JW Louw J and Keightley AJ
Summary: criminal law. fundamental rights. rights of mentally disabled complainants in criminal cases. failed to address question of mental disability under s 1 of criminal law amendment act 32 of 2007. further failure to secure appropriate psychological expert evidence led to further violation of rights. secondary victimisation by presiding officer and prosecutor by calling complainant into court to determine themselves if mentally disabled. violation of rights to privacy, dignity, bodily integrity.

Judges: CP Rabie J and A Basson J
Summary: criminal law. murder. attempted murder. evidence to sustain charges. appellant fired shots at deceased after being assaulted in tavern; bystander also shot and wounded. immediately turned himself in. state witnesses contradicting themselves and each other. error in rejection of appellant's version. reasonably possible acted in defence of life. conviction and sentences set aside.

Judges: AC Basson J and DS Fourie J
Summary: criminal law. appeal. application for leave to appeal. no merit in application, no reasonable prospect of another court coming to different conclusion. evidence overwhelming. application dismissed.

Judges: Janse Van Nieuwenhuizen J and Mabuse J
Summary: criminal law. rape. sentence. life imprisonment. minimum sentence in terms of criminal law amendment act 105 of 1997. 'substantial and compelling circumstances'. recorded fact that rape not pre.planned and alcohol as substantial and compelling circumstances to impose lesser sentence. sentence does not induce sense of shock. appeal dismissed.

Judges: Francis J and Louw J
Summary: criminal law. appeal. generally. trial court's evaluation of evidence. totality of evidence indicative of appellant's guilt. appellant's version of complainant's mother using her to implicate him, could not reasonably possibly be true and is clearly false. due regard was had to child witness minor discrepancies in testimony. sentence reduced to 20 years' imprisonment.

Judges: DS Fourie J
Summary: criminal law. bail. appeal against refusal of. from magistrate's court to high court. convicted of housebreaking with intent to steal and theft of goods to amount of r55 000 and sentenced to 5 years imprisonment of which 2 were suspended. no real prospects of success on conviction. appeal dismissed.

Judges: C Swanepoel AJ (DS Molefe J concurring)
Summary: criminal law. murder. mens rea. intent to kill. dolus eventualis. whether present. beating sickly man with tree branch repeatedly over head and body causing subdural haemorrhage to large parts of head. must have realised putting life at risk. guilty in form of dolus eventualis.

Judges: DT Skosana AJ and N Janse Van Niewenhuizen J
Summary: criminal law. rape. sufficiency of evidence to support charge. appellant admitting intercourse but claiming consent. assessment of evidence. no grounds for interference with magistrate's credibility findings. appeal dismissed.

Judges: Hughes J and De Vries AJ
Summary: criminal law. rape. sentence. life imprisonment. minimum sentence in terms of criminal law amendment act 105 of 1997. 'substantial and compelling circumstances'. rape of 1.year.old girl. each case to be decided on own merit. appellant previous conviction for rape. on parole when committed offences which presently convicted of. no misdirection in sentence on count 1. appeal dismissed.

Judges: TM Makgoka J and K Manamela AJ
Summary: criminal law. removal and use of property without the authority of the owner. contravention of s 1(1) of the general law amendment act 50 of 1956. competent verdict to theft. evidence did not establish theft. sentence imposed wholly suspended.

Judges: MW Msimeki J and NM Mavundla J
Summary: criminal law. trial. resumption of where magistrate contract expired. query as to how matter came to be heard as special review revealed that contract of magistrate dealing with matter had expired. case may proceed before another magistrate. no order made, it being within state's right to charge accused de novo before another magistrate.

Judges: Sardiwalla AJ
Summary: criminal law. conservation. conspiracy to hunt rhinoceros in national park. should have been s 57 and not s 46 of act, cured by s 88 of cpa. carefully planned. rhino.poaching endemic. no misdirection in sentence. national environmental management protected areas act 57 of 2003, s 57(1).

Judges: LD Vukeya AJ and SAM Baqwa J
Summary: criminal law. appeal. conviction and sentence. evidence of witnesses to multiple robberies not assailable. firearm used. complainants not hurt. less than minimum sentences applied. appeals dismissed.

Judges: MJ Mushasha AJ and NV Khumalo J
Summary: criminal law. rape. sentence. complainant under age of 16 years. complainant showed no indication of any negative psychological problems. medical report reflects good mental health and emotional status. no physical injuries observed. acquiescent conduct on part of complainant. proceeded on own accord in 2 instances to appellant's home. sentenced reduced to 20 years' imprisonment on each count.

Judges: NV Khumalo J and K LaM Manamela AJ
Summary: criminal law. rape. sentence. rape of 41.year.old woman. serious injuries inflicted when overpowering complainant in open veld. appellant aged 23 and pleading guilty. all relevant aspects properly considered by court a quo and no misdirection in finding absence of substantial and compelling factors. imposition of prescribed life term confirmed, and appeal dismissed.

Judges: Kubushi J
Summary: criminal law. appeal. generally. trial court's evaluation of evidence. presumption that findings of fact are correct. if there is no misdirection, the court of appeal will interfere therewith only if it is convinced that such evaluation is wrong. appeal dismissed.

Judges: TJ Raulinga J and S Strauss AJ
Summary: criminal law. evidence. assessment of. sexual offences. number of contradictions from complainant and material contradictions in evidence of other witnesses. further, no medical reports to corroborate evidence of first complainant. single witness. state could not offer acceptable explanation for discrepancies, result in difficulty to discharge onus. appeal against conviction upheld.

Judges: FG Preller J and MF Kganyago AJ
Summary: criminal law. rape. sentence. life imprisonment. minimum sentence in terms of criminal law amendment act 105 of 1997. 'substantial and compelling circumstances'. court a quo failed to give appellant's unfortunate background any weight in consideration of sentence. not properly addressed in pre.sentencing report. also overlooked gradation of seriousness of different kinds of rape. present crime did not call for heaviest sentence. personal circumstances cumulatively constitute substantial and compelling circumstances. convictions of rape on count 2 and 3 set aside, substituted with sexual assault, counts 1, 2, 3, 4, 5 and 7 taken together for purposes of sentence and 10 years' imprisonment imposed.

Judges: VT Mtati AJ and T Maumela J
Summary: criminal law. evidence\'97 sufficiency of. culpable homicide and driving under influence of alcohol \'97 single witness not reliable without corroboration. convictions and sentences on all charges set aside, apart from driving without valid driver's licence. sentence of r1000 or 3 months' imprisonment, wholly suspended, confirmed. national road traffic act 93 of 1996, s 65(1)(a).

Judges: MJ Teffo J and SA Thobane AJ
Summary: criminal law. fundamental rights. fair trial. late introduction of dna evidence after close of state case. in interests of justice and appellant suffered no legally recognisable prejudice. conviction for rape confirmed. age 23 and first offender. no misdirection in finding of substantial and compelling circumstances and sentence of 20 years confirmed.

Judges: Kubushi J
Summary: criminal law. sentence. prescribed sentences. minimum sentences. imposition of in terms of criminal law amendment act 105 of 1997. 'substantial and compelling circumstances'. viewed individually appellant's personal circumstances cannot be regarded as substantial and compelling. however, considered cumulatively and balanced against circumstances pertaining to commission of offence and interests of society, ought to have characterised as such. sentence reduced to 10 years' imprisonment.

Judges: TA Maumela J and JJ Strijdom AJ
Summary: criminal law. sentence. factors to be taken into account. element of mercy infused in sentence passed. tempers approach when considering basic factors of letting punishment fit criminal as well as crime and being fair to society. appellant has not demonstrated sentence meted out was shockingly inappropriate. appeal dismissed.

Judges: VV Tlhapi J and FG Preller J
Summary: criminal law. evidence. assessment of. totality of evidence. on own version of appellant he returned to purchaser to collect monies due on items sold. probability is responded as seller of stolen items. thus not necessary to call state witnesses who could testify to this fact. magistrate took into account possession of items shortly after offence committed. conviction in order.

Judges: N Ranchod J and SAM Baqwa J
Summary: criminal law. evidence. witnesses. credibility. single witness. contradictions to be treated with caution. to be kept in mind not every error and contradiction affects credibility of witness. complainant's evidence viewed holistically must not be rejected in toto. appeals dismissed.

Judges: PD Phahlane AJ
Summary: criminal law. evidence. circumstantial evidence. assessment of. deceased last seen leaving with accused by colleague and not returning to work. evidence of police officer taking pointing.out unsupported by direct evidence and rejected as not credible. insufficient evidence to support charges of kidnapping, murder, rape, and aggravated robbery. acquitted on all counts.

Judges: FW Botes AJ, Makgoba J and Jansen J
Summary: criminal law. sentences. prescribed sentences. minimum sentence. imposition of in terms of criminal law amendment act 105 of 1997. 'substantial and compelling circumstances'. sentence may be interfered with if sentence discretion exercised improperly or unreasonably, or induced sense of shock or startlingly inappropriate. sentence imposed intended to break appellant. youthful first offender, with possibility of rehabilitation. sentence on count 1, 2, 5 and 6 confirmed, sentence on murder conviction reduced to 20 years' imprisonment.

Judges: SA Thobane AJ and S Potterill J
Summary: criminal law. evidence. assessment of. mutually destructive factual accounts. conspectus of all evidence required. necessary cautionary rules applied by court a quo. considered totality of evidence. guilt established beyond reasonable doubt. appeal dismissed, convictio and sentence confirmed.

Judges: MW Msimeki J, E Bertelsmann J and AML Phatudi J
Summary: criminal law. sentence. prescribed sentences. minimum sentences. imposition of in terms of criminal law amendment act 105 of 1997. generally. court alive to fact that triad key in determination of sentence. no demonstrable and material misdirections or irregularities in way trial court exercised discretion. appeal fails.

Judges: S Potterill J and N Kollapen J
Summary: criminal law. review. special review. legal representative of accused not admitted and did not have right of appearance. proceedings thus irregular resulting in miscarriage of justice. proceedings set aside and trial to start de novo.

Judges: Hughes J
Summary: criminal law. evidence. assessment of. identification. complainant knew both accused facially. lighting also very good at time of incident. appellant failed to testify in light of direct evidence identifying him as perpetrator. appeal fails.

Judges: Mngadi AJ
Summary: criminal law. evidence. witnesses. credibility. single witness. robbed in shack at gunpoint of r3500 cash and other items. necessary caution not exercised. identification not meeting required standard of proof. appeal upheld and convictions and sentences set aside.

Judges: HJ Fabricius J, WRC Prinsloo J and NV Khumalo J
Summary: criminal law. murder. sentence. appeal. part of group who broke into home and shot deceased, robbed and raped girlfriend when she arrived home. no misdirection. nothing in appellant's favour. sentences of life imprisonment for murder, 15 years on each of 2 counts of rape and 15 years for aggravated robbery, confirmed.

Judges: VRSN Nkosi AJ and W Msimeki J
Summary: criminal law. housebreaking with intent to steal and theft. sentence. induces sense of shock, court entitled to interfere. court failed to consider both accused as equals, disparity in sentence, yet committed and convicted of same offence. sentence set aside and replaced with 12 months imprisonment with conditions as per contained in order.

Judges: Maluleke J and Makume J
Summary: criminal law. evidence. of identification. identification parade. complied with all rules and requirements. identity of appellant also proven beyond reasonable doubt. appellant correctly convicted on all counts. sentences on robbery convictions reduced to 13 years' imprisonment on each count, to run concurrently.

Judges: MD Mohlamonyane AJ and MHE Ismail J
Summary: criminal law. evidence. accomplice evidence. evaluation of. vehicle found in possession of accused no 2, implicated appellant. whether appellant stole vehicle. no motive on accused no 2 to implicate. conviction confirmed, sentence reduced to 5 years' imprisonment.

Judges: S Potterill J and N Kollapen J
Summary: criminal law. evidence. accomplice evidence. evaluation of. evidence of witness warned in terms of s 204 of criminal procedure act 51 of 1977. magistrate adhered to cautionary rule applicable although not expressly say so. did not err in accepting evidence as reliable and truthful \'97corroborated by independent evidence. appeal dismissed.

Judges: NB Tuchten J and MJ Mushasha AJ
Summary: criminal law. evidence. adequacy of proof. onus of proof on state. whether version of accused to be rejected. 4 deficiencies in stock of business. sole responsibility of appellant. signed acknowledgment of debt on first discovery. defence signed upon advise of co.worker. further deficiencies not reported blamed on being overworked. only employee with opportunity. appeal dismissed, sentence reduced taking into account personal circumstances.

Judges: LM Molopa-Sethosa J and NP Mngqibisa-Thusi J
Summary: criminal law. trial. right to a fair trial. rights to legal representation and bail not explained\'97 conviction and sentence for entering or remaining in the country unlawfully and cruelty to animals set aside on special review.

Judges: K Makhafola J
Summary: criminal law. bail. appeal against refusal of. charge robbery aggravating circumstances. 2 bail applications before same magistrate. second application procedure untenable and bad in law. to remit to hear on new facts would not be fair and just. appeal succeeds, bail granted.

Judges: Holland-M\'fcter AJ and Khumalo J
Summary: criminal law. robbery. aggravating circumstances. evidence sufficient to sustain charge. witness credible. appellant's version highly improbable. found guilty on basis of common purpose. conviction in order. firearm used and r12 000 taken. first offender. no reason to interfere with finding by court a quo that substantial and compelling circumstances present and imposition of 12 years' imprisonment. appeal dismissed.

Judges: AJ Bam J and S Potterill J
Summary: criminal law. review. automatic review. unrepresented accused. all elements of theft not proven. statement made indicates breach of contractual obligation not theft. plea of not guilty in terms of s 113 of criminal procedure act 51 of 1977 should have been entered. conviction and sentence set aside.

Judges: PD Phahlane AJ and SAM Baqwa J
Summary: criminal law. murder. sentence. assaulted and strangled female deceased. first offender, 39 years of age with borderline intellectual impairment. intellectual impairment should have been considered mitigating factor. all factors cumulatively considered constituted substantial and compelling circumstances. life term replaced with 20 years' imprisonment.

Judges: Nair AJ and CP Rabie J
Summary: criminal law. appeal. record. record lost, destroyed or incomplete. question whether defects in record so serious that proper consideration of appeal not possible cannot be answered in abstract. clerk unable to assemble all role players to assist in reconstruction of record. 7 and a half year delay since trial, improbable prosecutor, attorney and accused would make meaningful contributions. manner in which was reconstructed and constitutional imperative that an accused is entitled to fair trial. proceedings not in accordance with justice and all convictions and sentences are set aside.

Judges: N Kollapen J and SS Mphahlele J
Summary: criminal law. rape. evidence to sustain charges. misdirection by court a quo in dismissing contradictions in evidence of single witness as immaterial. case not proved beyond reasonable doubt on totality of evidence. conviction and sentence accordingly set aside.

Judges: C Pretorius J and J Du Plessis AJ
Summary: criminal law. murder. evidence sufficient to sustain charges. convicted on evidence of accomplice. single, accomplice witness not properly warned in terms s 204 of criminal procedure act 51 of 1977. contradicted herself in material ways. case not proved beyond a reasonable doubt. all 4 convictions and sentences set aside on appeal.

Judges: JJ Strijdom AJ and Kubushi
Summary: criminal law. sentence. prescribed sentence. minimum sentences. imposition of in terms of criminal law amendment act 105 of 1997. 'substantial and compelling circumstances'. period in detention is but 1 of factors to be taken into account. its not considered on own a substantial and compelling circumstance, but whether effective sentence proposed proportionate to crime committed. appeal dismissed.

Judges: PM Mabuse J and N Ranchod J
Summary: criminal law. review. special review. sentence. not clear whether counts taken together for purposes of sentence or on which count 10.year term of imprisonment imposed. sentence accordingly incompetent and set aside. matter remitted to magistrate to impose sentence afresh.

Judges: Hughes J and Molefe J
Summary: criminal law. review. in terms of rule 53 of uniform rules of court. failure to follow procedure embedded within rule. no notification to affected parties. also calls for affected parties to show cause. applicant magistrate was not presiding officer involved in proceedings when alleged irregularity committed. no evidence of gross irregularity on record provided. matter erroneously submitted on review.

Judges: MF Legodi J and D Thulare AJ
Summary: criminal law. rape. robbery aggravating. sentence. both appellants having previous convictions. accosted woman who was on her way to work in the early morning. threatened with a knife. robbed of her cellphone and then raped by each appellant. life sentences for rape and 15 years for robbery aggravating.

Judges: Nobanda AJ, VV Tlhapi J and Louw J
Summary: criminal law. evidence. identification. assessment. multiple counts including murder, aggravated robbery, arms and ammunition charges and murder. single witness to murder clear and satisfactory. failure of appellant to testify conclusive of involvement in face of damaging evidence. convicted on basis of dolus eventualis on murder count. first offender and 25 years of age. not warned of possibility of life term for murder, however, and no evidence murder premeditated. appeal against convictions dismissed but life term imposed for murder set aside and replaced with 15 years, sentences on other counts ordered to run concurrently with this sentence.

Judges: WRC Prinsloo J, AP Ledwaba J and N Kollapen J
Summary: criminal law. evidence. witnesses. credibility. single witness and trap. cautionary rules. corroboration found in medical evidence. plus fact no other conceivable person that could have raped complainant. further corroboration in behaviour of complainant after incidents. appeal dismissed.

Judges: MF Legodi J, JR Murphy J and CP Rabie J
Summary: criminal law. sentence. murder. accused accompanying drunk victim in vehicle after night at tavern. victim beaten to death. accused driving on in his vehicle. murder convictions and sentences of 20 years and 10 years confirmed. robbery aggravating conviction replaced with theft.

Judges: Janse van Nieuwenhuizen J and Moloto AJ
Summary: criminal law. evidence. assessment of. identification. favourable conditions present on day and time of incident for witness to correctly identify appellant. witness knew appellants prior to the incident. appeal fails to be dismissed against conviction of robbery.

Judges: JR Murphy J and C Pretorius J
Summary: criminal law. review. special review. came to court's attention via notification from law society attorney who represented accused had never been admitted as such. irregularity constitutes a failure of justice. proceedings of court a quo set aside and to be instituted de novo.

Judges: Makhoba J, Raulinga J and Kollapen J
Summary: criminal law. evidence. confession. admissibility of. must be made freely and voluntarily. entrenched in constitution and criminal procedure act 51 of 1977. if magistrate or person taking statement notes injuries statement should not be taken. appeal upheld, convictions and sentences set aside.

Judges: PM Mabuse J and SC Mia AJ
Summary: criminal law. rape. evidence to sustain charge. appellant admitting to having sexual intercourse with 13.year.old complainant on several occasions. complainant disputing that consented. no misdirection by court a quo in rejecting appellant's claim of consent on assessment of totality of evidence. conviction confirmed. no misdirection in imposition of prescribed life term.

Defendant: Masenya 2017 JDR 0913 (GP) \'97 Now reported at 2018 (1) SACR 407 (GP)
Judges: HJ Fabricius J, P Rabie J, F Legodi J
Summary: criminal law. sentence. prescribed minimum sentences. criminal law (sentencing) amendment act 105 of 1997. misdirection by court a quo in erroneously regarding accused as falling within ambit of item (a)(iii) act where convicted in same trial on same day for multiple counts of rape. sentence set aside, and sentence considered and imposed.

Judges: De Vos J and Van Der Westhuizen AJ
Summary: criminal law. review. special review. sentence. suspended condition pertaining to compensation wrongly made in terms of s 300 instead of s 297(1)(i)(aa) of criminal procedure act 51 of  1977. reference to s 300 accordingly deleted. sentences otherwise confirmed. order that counts be taken together for purpose of sentence clearly nonsensical (separate sentences imposed on each count) and set aside.

Judges: WRC Prinsloo J; PA Meyer J and JW Louw J
Summary: criminal law. murder. evidence sufficient to sustain charges. multiple charges including (1) murder, (2) attempted murder and (3) housebreaking with intent to rob and robbery. misdirection in inferring that appellant knew that attackers had weapon with them. accordingly no common purpose for counts (1) and (2) but present for lesser verdict on (3) of housebreaking with intent to steal and theft. sentence for count 3 reduced from 18 to 8 years, sentences for remaining counts to be served concurrently and accordingly reduced to effective 3 years.

Judges: Rossouw AJ and AP Ledwaba DJP
Summary: criminal law. review. sentence. 8 year sentence exceeding magistrate's jurisdiction of 3 years. housebreaking with intent to steal and theft. sentence replaced with 1 of 3 years. section 304(4) of the criminal procedure act 51 of 1977.

Judges: MJ Teffo J and M Madima AJ
Summary: criminal law. rape. evidence sufficient to sustain charge. rape of 10.year.old boy by neighbour. caught in act by witness in his caravan. supported by medical evidence. conviction in order. no cross.appeal filed regarding sentence therefore no interference despite obvious leniency.

Judges: M Madima AJ and MJ Teffo J
Summary: criminal law. housebreaking. intent steal and theft. fingerprint evidence not countered. previous conviction for same offence. house ransacked and goods of value r34 000 taken. 8 year sentence confirmed on appeal.

Judges: C Pretorius J and DS Molefe
Summary: criminal law. indictment and charge. splitting of charges. duplication of convictions. convicted of escaping lawful custody and fraud. 2 crimes committed with single intent, to escape custody. action to commit fraud to enable escape not defraud anyone. second count of fraud set aside. sentence set aside and remitted for sentencing.

Defendant: Masango 2015 JDR 2174 (GP) \'97 Now reported at 2017 (1) SACR 571 (GP)
Judges: AML Phatudi J, NM Mavundla J and C Pretorius J
Summary: criminal law. sentence. evidence received before sentencing. section 274 of the criminal procedure act 51 of 1977. section not adequately complied with. sentences based on insufficient evidence in mitigation. matter remitted to sentencing court to hear evidence in mitigation.

Judges: Mudau AJ
Summary: criminal law. evidence. assessment of. identification. no identification parade held. aided in identification by moonlight during initial stages of incident, seated in back seat with him. close proximity to appellant. complainant's boyfriend corroborated her evidence. appeal dismissed.

Judges: WRC Prinsloo J, TM Makgoka J and JW Louw J
Summary: criminal law. sentence. prescribed minimum sentence. criminal law amendment act 105 of 1997. misdirection by court a quo in applying provisions of s 51 to appellant (age 17 at commission of offence). effective life term reduced to effective sentence of 22 years.

Judges: Ranchod J; AA Louw J and Molahlehi AJ
Summary: criminal law. murder. sentence. firearm and ammunition charges. multiple shots at female partner. court a quo accepted that crime of passion. globular sentence of 30 years disturbingly inappropriate. reduced to 20 years on appeal.

Judges: NV Khumalo J (N Kollapen J concurring)
Summary: criminal law. verdict. competent verdicts. convicted of housebreaking with intent to steal and theft. questioning in terms of s 212 (b) of the criminal procedure act 51 of 1977, evident no intent to steal prior to entering dwelling nor did accuse break into dwelling to gain access. all elements not met. convicted of theft as competent verdict. sentence reduced.

Judges: De Vos J and Kubushi J
Summary: criminal law. housebreaking with intent to steal and theft. sentence. multiple other charges relating to attempted break.in of bottle store and assaults on girlfriend. attempted break.in carefully planned. no leniency for person carrying firearm and attempting to break into business premises at night, and who uses brutal force against women. effective sentence of 10 years' imprisonment not unreasonable. appeal dismissed.

Judges: MM Jansen J and N Khumalo J
Summary: criminal law. murder. sentence. misdirection by trial court in tarring appellant with brush of his co.accused who is hardened criminal. failed to take age of appellant, fact that first offender and circumstances under which committed. appellant sentenced to 15 years' imprisonment on each count, sentences to run concurrently.

Judges: CP Rabie J and J Hattingh AJ
Summary: criminal law. rape. evidence sufficient to sustain charges. complainant alleging that ex.boyfriend kidnapped and raped her repeatedly. conflicting accounts given by complainant and witnesses. appellant's version not inherently improbable. case not proved beyond reasonable doubt. appeal upheld and conviction and sentence set aside.

Judges: MM Jansen J and Kganyago AJ
Summary: criminal law. rape. proof of. complainant was 15.year.old daughter of appellant. expelled from school attended for misbehaviour. in consistencies and improbabilities in version, appeared minor was, in general, in miscreant who behaved badly for unknown reasons. appellant's version supported by witness. appeal upheld.

Judges: JW Louw J and AJ Bam J
Summary: criminal law. traffic offences. driving with an excessive concentration of alcohol in the blood. accused pleading guilty, but not asked if admitted blood sample correctly analysed or whether admitted result of test. all elements of offence had not been admitted in terms of s 112(1)(b) of the criminal procedure act 51 of 1977. conviction cannot be upheld, conviction and sentence set aside.

Judges: NB Tuchten J and EM Kubushi J
Summary: criminal law. evidence. assessment of. only reasonable inference from totality of evidence was appellant was 1 of 5 robbers and suffered gunshot wound at scene of robbery. appellant's version of innocently obtaining lift, being pulled over by police and shot while searched is absurd. appeal against conviction dismissed and sentence confirmed.

Judges: Tuchten J
Summary: criminal law. indictment and charge. charge of robbery. special review. rights re prescribed sentence not explained though reference to criminal law amendment act 105 of 1977 in heading of charge. attorney concerned that accused at risk of minimum sentence though charge lacking facts constituting aggravated circumstances. accused only liable in circumstances to be sentenced in terms of normal court jurisdiction anyway, therefore unnecessary to intervene. matter remitted to regional court for continuation of trial.

Judges: NB Tuchten J and S Mokose AJ
Summary: criminal law. indictment and charge. objection to charge. rape charge formulated in 3 separate ways when put to appellant. no misdirection as appellant and his counsel knew from outset what case had to meet. conviction in order. appeal dismissed.

Judges: NV Khumalo J and Mushasha AJ
Summary: criminal law. leave to appeal. application for. requirements. existence of reasonable prospect of success. whole body of evidence considered in totality lends credence to version of complainant, casts serious doubt to that of appellant and his alibi. no prospects of another court arriving at different conclusion. application for leave dismissed.

Judges: Molefe J
Summary: criminal law. arms and ammunition. unlawful possession of firearm in contravention of s 4 of firearms control act 60 of 2000. sentence. beretta semi.automatic pistol. no evidence that was indeed semi.automatic therefore s 51(2) of criminal law amendment act 105 of 1997 not applicable. sentence of 15 years' imprisonment reduced to 3 years on appeal.

Judges: Bam J
Summary: criminal law. bail. application for. factors to be taken into account. 'exceptional circumstances' as contemplated in s 60(11)(a) of criminal procedure act 51 of 1977. failed to convince exceptional circumstances exist justifying granting of bail. clearly certain material discrepancies and inconsistencies in respective versions, but not in agreement state's case is weak. appeal dismissed.

Judges: Francis J
