Summary: criminal law. police. liability of. vicarious liability of employer for delictual acts of employee. deviation test. wrongdoing took place outside the course and scope of employment. no sufficiently close connection to the employment of second defendant. first defendant cannot be held liable. was off duty at the time, had a weapon which had not been issued to him, was not in uniform for plaintiff to have reposed his trust in second defendant. absolution from the instance order granted.

Judges: AC Basson J, C Pretorius J and NB Tuchten J
Summary: criminal law. murder. sentence. life imprisonment. highest sanction not to be imposed lightly even though prescribed as minimum sentence. in circumstances of this case sentence not shockingly inappropriate. premeditated murder for personal gain. shot in cold blood, 4 times. appeal dismissed.

Judges: Jansen AJ and PM Mabuse J
Summary: criminal law. review. special review in terms of s 304 (4) of criminal procedure act 51 of 1977. came to light pre.sentencing that accused no 2 was a minor. to be dealt with in accordance with provisions of child justice act 75 of 2008. conviction set aside, proceedings to start ab initio in terms of child justice act 75 of 2008.

Judges: Magardie AJ and Rabie J
Summary: criminal law. evidence. to sustain 2 counts of robbery with aggravating circumstances. complainants hit on respective heads with bottle at tavern by friend of appellant. appellant removing items during assaults. acting in common purpose with perpetrator discounted though guilty of 2 counts of robbery on own account. appellant's conduct not, however, constituting robbery with aggravating circumstances and minimum sentences therefore not applicable. sentence of 15 years on each count replaced by 3 years partially suspended, ordered to run concurrently.

Judges: A Van Niekerk AJ and C Cambanis AJ
Summary: criminal law. appeal. against conviction and sentence. rape. evidence of complainant was not unreliable. medical evidence corroborated her evidence. court acutely aware evidence of single witness. inconsistencies and contradictions not material when considered cumulatively. no misdirection. took appellant's personal circumstances into account, imposed lenient sentence of 15 years' imprisonment. appeal dismissed.

Judges: Mavundla J and Bam AJ
Summary: criminal law. sentence. murder. sustained and drunken assault on lover with fists and boots. lover dying from injuries. age 29, never attended school. alcohol playing part. no substantial and compelling circumstances. 15 years, with 1 year deducted for year spent in custody before conviction and sentencing.

Judges: Poswa J and Sapire AJ
Summary: criminal law. crimen injuria. what constitutes. appellant convicted of crimen injuria and sentenced to fine of r1200 or 8 months' imprisonment. on appeal against conviction and sentence. words uttered by appellant had nothing to do with complainant's dignity. appellant describing what he would physically do to complainant which was far from insulting him. appellant was wrongly convicted. conviction and sentence set aside.

Judges: Tuchten J
Summary: criminal law. fundamental rights. right to human dignity. methods of restrain (leg irons and chains) infringes right to dignity. not direct attack at constitutionality in appropriate circumstances of chain restraint. section 205(3) of the constitution requires police to take reasonable steps to ensure people in their custody do not escape. right of applicant to dignity balanced against obligations of police under s 205(3) of the constitution. applicant had already attempted to escape previously. chain restraint 1 of ways to fulfil constitutional mandate and in circumstances a legitimate way of achieving that purpose. applications dismissed.

Judges: Thulare AJ
Summary: criminal law. bail. appeal against refusal of. state has prima facie case against appellant 1 and 2 on charge of conspiracy to murder. same cannot be said for appellant 3 and 4. state relies on statements made by appellants, which may be ruled inadmissible due to being tortured and to confess. appellant 3 and 4 showed exceptional circumstances exist in interests of justice permitting release on bail. appeal by appellant 1 and 2 dismissed, appellant 3 and 4 released on bail subject to certain conditions.

Judges: Bam J and Potterill J
Summary: criminal law. sentence. fraud. misrepresenting qualifications and service tags for servicing of fire extinguishers. accused having committed fraud, but assumption made that accused did not service the extinguishers, which effected the sentence of 3 years imprisonment. sentence altered to 12 months, of which 6 months suspended.

Judges: Tolmay J and C Pretorius J
Summary: criminal law. trial. record. fire at magistrates' court. reconstruction of record not possible. proceedings set aside. matter referred back to magistrates' court to start afresh.

Judges: S P Mothle J and E Jordaan J
Summary: criminal law. trial. presiding officer. duties of. accused not legally represented. explanation of accused's rights. material omission vitiates entire proceedings. both conviction and sentence are set aside.

Judges: Molefe AJ, Phatudi J and Hassim AJ
Summary: criminal law. common purpose. intent. stabbing during robbery. identity of accused also in issue on appeal. appeal against conviction dismissed. sentence reduced from life to 18 and 15 years on the 2 counts.

Judges: Kollapen J
Summary: criminal law. rape. evidence to sustain 2 counts of rape. complainant assaulted, threatened with firearm and raped on 2 different occasions. appellant contending in relationship and intercourse consensual. complainant corroborated by friend. both credible witnesses. version of appellant so improbable fell to be rejected. substantial and compelling circumstances not present. sentence of 10 years' imprisonment on each count, ordered to run concurrently, not excessive or evoking sense of shock. appeal against conviction and sentence dismissed.

Judges: Dosio AJ and Stijdom AJ
Summary: criminal law. murder. sentence. accused used okapi knife to stab and kill 2 men during initiation celebrations. 2 15.year sentences, to run concurrently. appealing convictions and sentences. appeals dismissed.

Judges: Matojane J and NS Masango AJ
Summary: criminal law. appeal. generally. trial court's evaluation of evidence. presumption that trial court's findings of fact are correct. presumption also applicable in cases involving application of cautionary rule relating to child witnesses and/or single witnesses. magistrate approached evidence of complainant with necessary caution. appeal dismissed.

Judges: K Manamela AJ and EM Makgoba J
Summary: criminal law. review. in what cases. gross irregularity in proceedings as envisaged by s 24(1)(c) of supreme court act 59 of 1959. accused plead guilty to same charge twice and plead to offence already convicted for. right to a fair trial is paramount, a 35(3)(m) of the constitution. trial or proceedings of 19th july 2013 are set aside, trial or proceedings of 17th october 2013 to proceed.

Judges: Vorster AJ and Molefe AJ
Summary: criminal law. robbery. evidence. assessment of. identification. appellant alleging not person who robbed complainant. witnesses could see properly due to apollo light \'97chased from moment of robbery until apprehended. complainant's items found in his possession. identification reliable. no misdirection in sentencing. 2 year's imprisonment appropriate. appeal against conviction and sentence dismissed.

Judges: RG Tolmay J and C Pretorius
Summary: criminal law. juvenile offenders. trial. review. fifteen year old accused erroneously sentenced in terms of s 290(1)(d) of the criminal procedure act 51 of 1977. sentence defective as s 290 repealed by child justice act 75 of 2008. sentence set aside, referred back to court a quo for sentencing afresh.

Judges: NS Masango AJ and EM Kubushi J
Summary: criminal law. fraud. sentence. look to contribution of accomplice to commission of offence. appellant employed at mine, perpetrator not, and used appellant's access card to access mine. if not for appellant's contribution, providing access card, offence would not have been committed. blameworthiness equivalent of perpetrator. sentence of 3 years' imprisonment, 18 months suspended for 5 years, confirmed on appeal.

Judges: Cambanis AJ and De Vos J
Summary: criminal law. robbery. aggravating circumstances. victim throttled unconscious. no remorse. sentence of 15 years confirmed on appeal. second conviction of robbery set aside because evidence of identification not sufficient.

Judges: Van Niekerk J and Kruger AJ
Summary: criminal law. rape. sentence. complainant own daughter of age 15. life sentence imposed by trial court which found no substantial and compelling circumstances. appellant first offender, pleaded guilty but showed no remorse. age 40. did not injure daughter but threatened to kill her if she spoke out. life sentence replaced with 1 of 15 years.

Judges: Teffo J, Makhubela AJ and Strijdom AJ
Summary: criminal law. murder and attempted murder. mens rea. intention to kill. claiming did not foresee death as intellectual functioning impaired due to alcohol and drugs. court a quo accepting that intellectual functioning impaired, but finding behaviour not consistent with complete loss of reason. no grounds for interference with findings. sentence of 25 years for murder not disturbingly inappropriate. appeal against convictions and sentence dismissed.

Judges: NV Khumalo J and LM Molopa-Sethosa J
Summary: criminal law. review. special review in terms of s 304(4) of criminal procedure act 51 of 1977. exceeded jurisdiction in terms of s 112(1)(a) of act 51 of 1977. misdirected himself by passing sentence even if wholly suspended. sentence imposition a nullity in law and warrants being set aside. sentence set aside, remitted to court a quo for sentencing afresh.

Defendant: SJM 2013 JDR 2149 (GNP) \'97 Now reported at 2014 (1) SACR 363 (GP)
Judges: Tolmay J and C Pretorius J
Summary: criminal law. juvenile offenders. trial. review. murder. at time of sentencing accused had just turned 18 and was refused access by youth care facility as no longer a child. age of accused at date of commission of offence relevant for purpose of sentencing, s 4 read with s 76 of the child justice act 75 of 2008. child justice act continues in operation where child turns 18 during course of proceedings. section 76 still a competent sentence for a child who turns 18 during course of proceedings but is under age of 21. youth care facility refusal not accordance with constitution or child justice act.

Judges: Msimeki J and Makhubele AJ
Summary: criminal law. maintenance. maintenance order. crisp issue whether maintenance order which alleged to have contravened even existed. order not signed by magistrate, as result, of no force and effect. no basis for charging appellant. appeal against sentence and conviction succeeds.

Judges: Kubushi J and Phatudi J
Summary: criminal law. theft. sentence. accused aged 31. stole cabling. items recovered. pleaded guilty. 2 minor children. first offender. 12 months suspended for 5 years.

Judges: EM Kubushi J, Ledwaba DJP, Sidlova AJ and Maumela J
Summary: criminal law. sentence. prescribed sentences. imposition of in terms of criminal law amendment act 105 of 1997. 'substantial and compelling circumstances'. appellant played leading role, finding that murder premeditated. personal circumstances overshadowed by moral blameworthiness. sentence appropriate and not disproportionate to totality of appellant's mitigating factors. appeal dismissed.

Judges: N Kollapen J and FG Preller J and HL Alberts AJ
Summary: criminal law. appeal. against conviction and sentence. failure to call witness in terms of s 186 of criminal procedure act 51 of 1977. failure not constitute an irregularity justify setting aside conviction. value of witness weighed up, and election by both state and defence case to not call witness. discretion exercised correctly. conviction for murder upheld, attempted murder set aside, sentence reduced to 12 years imprisonment.

Judges: Phatudi AJ and Khumalo J
Summary: criminal law. sentence. housebreaking. previous offence 9 years before. effectively a first offender. stolen items worth r748 recovered on the spot. sentence of 8 years imprisonment set aside and replaced with 3 years, wholly suspended for 5 years.

Judges: Ranchod J and Fabricius J
Summary: criminal law. review. special review in terms of s 304a of criminal procedure act 51 of 1977. convicted on count of housebreaking with intent to steal and theft. previously suspended sentence put into operation. proper enquiry not conducted to put suspended sentence into effect. set aside and referred to court a quo to deal with application of putting suspended sentence into operation.

Judges: NB Tuchten J and C Pretorius J
Summary: criminal law. drug offences. dagga. dealing in in contravention of s 5(b) of drugs and drug trafficking act 140 of 1992. sentence. accused in possession of 150kg, sentenced to 6 years imprisonment, and in addition fine of r50 000. disparate positions adopted by appellant as to financial means. for purposes of sentence claimed to be poor and unemployed. purposes of leave to appeal claimed to be in position to pay a fine and begged for opportunity to do so. appellant far from impoverished victim. sentence and conviction confirmed.

Judges: Goodey AJ and Engelbrecht AJ
Summary: criminal law. traffic offences. negligent driving. defences to. appellant convicted of reckless and negligent driving. on appeal against conviction. defense counsel raised defence of 'sudden emergency'. if appellant drove at reasonable speed with correct following distance between him and vehicle in front of him and kept proper lookout, he would have been able to avoid 'sudden emergency'. magistrate erred in convicting appellant of both reckless and negligent driving. appeal succeed. appellant found guilty of negligent driving.

Defendant: Sape 2012 JDR 1846 (GNP) \'97 Now reported at 2013 (1) SACR 330 (GNP)
Judges: Baqwa J
Summary: criminal law. rape. sentence. life imprisonment. minimum sentence in terms of criminal law amendment act 105 of 1997. no substantial and compelling circumstances exist to warrant deviation from minimum sentence. gave effect to deterrent and retributive aspects of punishment in protecting interests of society. accused not learnt from mistakes, danger to society. count 1 and 2 sentenced to 4 years imprisonment and counts 3, 4, 5, 6 and 8 sentenced to term of life imprisonment. sentences to run concurrently.

Defendant: Rudman 2013 JDR 0712 (GNP) \'97 Now reported at 2013 (2) SACR 209 (GNP)
Judges: Pretorius J
Summary: criminal law. murder. evidence required to sustain charge. accused parents of 2 month old baby. baby dying after suffering multiple injuries. accused denying culpability. injuries of sort no.one could have missed. at all relevant times in sole care of accused 1 and 2. 9 year old son of accused 1 seeing accused 2 hitting baby on head. accused 2 aware deceased being assaulted by accused 2 for considerable and continuous time before his death. both accused guilty of murder, accused 1 as accessory after the fact.

Judges: MJ Mushasha AJ and NV Khumalo J
Summary: criminal law. rape. sentence. life imprisonment. minimum sentence in terms of criminal law amendment act 105 of 1997. 'substantial and compelling circumstances'. factors in favour of appellant not constitute substantial and compelling circumstances. aggravating is the tender age of 12 of complainant and position of trust as stepfather. appeal dismissed.

Judges: SA Thobane AJ and S Potterill J
Summary: criminal law. appeal against sentence. rape of 11 year old. appellant a 70.year.old pensioner. court took into consideration age of appellant when imposing sentence as well as bad health. life imprisonment considered against correctional supervision. imprisonment only fitting sentence. fifteen years imprisonment sufficient. appeal dismissed.

Judges: G Webster J and HJ De Vos J
Summary: criminal law. appeal. generally. trial court's evaluation of evidence. can find no error in trial court's evaluation of evidence. no error or misdirection. therefore, no grounds existing for interference with convictions on appeal. accordingly, appeal against convictions dismissed.

Judges: A. De Vries AJ and Fabricius J
Summary: criminal law. evidence. confession. admissibility of. against another person. accused 2 and three's confessions used to convict and sentence appellant. contravention of s 219 of the criminal procedure act 51 of 1977. no reliance can be placed on evidence contained in confession against appellant. appellant is acquitted.

Judges: VRSN Nkosi J and C Cambanis AJ
Summary: criminal law. housebreaking with intent to steal and theft. sentence. lengthy term of imprisonment. appellant, first offender, convicted of 3 counts and sentenced to 12 years' imprisonment. court took into account all relevant personal circumstances. sentence not inducing sense of shock and confirmed.

Judges: MJ Teffo J and E Makgoba J
Summary: criminal law. review. special review in terms of s 304(4) of criminal procedure act 51 of 1977. fine imposed was competent, was an amount not exceeding that determined by minister in gazette. conviction in terms of s 112(1)(a), giving magistrate discretion to impose any competent sentence. conviction and sentence confirmed.

Judges: G Webster J and S Potterill J
Summary: criminal law. review. record. record destroyed and impossible to reconstruct. attempts to reconstruct but could not be done. court cannot order to start de novo. state has prerogative to take own decision. conviction and sentence to be set aside.

Judges: LM Molopa-Sethosa J and TA Maumela J
Summary: criminal law. review. special review in terms of s 304(4) of criminal procedure act 51 of 1977. incompetent sentence imposed by magistrates' court. as magistrate exceeded penal jurisdiction. sentence set aside and replaced with fine of r1500 or 6 months imprisonment.

Judges: Legodi J
Summary: criminal law. kidnapping and assault with intent to do grievous bodily harm. accused a game ranger. complainant caught allegedly poaching. accused reporting matter to police himself. assault conviction in order. queries as to kidnapping charge. circumstances not such that kidnapping for length of time accused of sustainable. kidnapping convictions adjusted. sentence reduced.

Judges: NM Mavundla J
Summary: criminal law. bail. appeal against refusal of. evidence. new evidence. medical problems of appellant are not new and does not amount to exceptional circumstances, warranting exercise of discretion to release on bail. appeal dismissed.

Judges: Pretorius J
Summary: criminal law. operation of 'ponzi' scheme. contravention of prevention of organised crime act 121 of 1998. sentencing.

Judges: Pretorius J
Summary: criminal law. opertion of 'ponzi' scheme. contravention of prevention of organised crime act 121 of 1998.

Defendant: PM 2014 JDR 0743 (GNP) \'97 Now reported at 2014 (2) SACR 481 (GP)
Judges: Thulare AJ
Summary: criminal law. murder. premeditated or planned murder. what constitutes. examination of all circumstances, including accused's state of mind, required for finding as to premeditating. accused acted calculatingly and rationally considered timing, likelihood of success. killing was act of power, revenge to show deceased's aunt with whom had a relationship. guilty on charge of murder and kidnapping.

Judges: Janse Van Nieuwenhuizen AJ, NS Makhafola J and Fourie J
Summary: criminal law. rape. sentence. factors to be taken into account. impact on complainant. ridiculed by peers and left school, extremely emotional, nightmares and did not want to sleep alone. undergone total personality change. suffered psychological damage which takes longer to heal than physical. perception physical injuries elevates rape to 'most serious' misplaced. appellant being married and children an aggravating factor. sentence upheld, sentenced to 25 years' imprisonment.

Defendant: Phiri 2013 JDR 1774 (GNP) \'97 Now reported at 2014 (1) SACR 211 (GNP)
Judges: Makgoka J and Baloyi AJ
Summary: criminal law. attempted murder. established law that knowingly infecting lover with hiv is attempted murder. dolus eventualis. judicial notice of fact that presently no cure and that infection is likely to lead to reduced lifespan. first offender, age 32 with 2 children. on appeal no reason to disturb sentence of 6 years.

Judges: Matojane J and Mngqibisa-Thusu J
Summary: criminal law. review. special review in terms of s304 of criminal procedure act 51 of 1977. child accused convicted on assault charge and sentenced in terms of s 76 of child care act 75 of 2008. 3 years compulsory residence at a youth care centre. returned to court to amend sentence as accuse kept absconding from centre. sentence amended accordingly.

Judges: EM Kubushi J and EM Makgoba J
Summary: criminal law. review. special review in terms of s 304a of criminal procedure act 51 of 1977. came to light post.conviction that complainant wished to withdraw charges against accused no 1 as he had not raped her. court questioned credibility of complainant and whether proceedings in accordance with justice. correct to have referred for review in terms of provisions of s304a of the act. case remitted to trial court to hear further evidence.

Judges: Baqwa J and Bam J
Summary: criminal law. fraud. what constitutes. appellant unlawfully credited a particular account when account not entitled to such credit. misrepresentation to bank. atm utilised to commit fraud. complainant withheld complainant credit card after store purchase. only inference can be drawn is appellant who made withdrawals without complainant consent. conviction confirmed, sentence reduced due to no previous convictions and not apparent to have propensity for crime. sentence suspended.

Judges: S Potterill J and SA Thobane AJ
Summary: criminal law. evidence. witnesses. children. when complainants in sexual offence cases. appointment of intermediary in terms of s 170a(1) of criminal procedure act 51 of 1977. points in limine. correct process followed in appointment of intermediary. no factual basis to allegation intermediary not consulted with complainants before, no oath administered to her and used as interpreter. appeal against conviction dismissed.

Judges: Strijdom AJ and Dosio AJ
Summary: criminal law. sentence. rape. 18 year sentence. 27.year.old accused, employed, married with 3 children. rape is rife and prevalent across our country. our courts are obliged to render a service to the community in endeavouring to send a warning to any prospective criminal to refrain from harassing and terrorising women. appeal against sentence dismissed.

Judges: Southwood J, Jordaan J and RD Claassen J
Summary: criminal law. rape. sentence. life imprisonment. appeal against conviction and sentence for rape. appellant convicted on 1 count of rape and 2 counts of indecent assault. taking all evidence into account state had not discharged onus of proving that appellant raped complainant. appellant admitting to indecently assaulting complainant on at least 6 occasions. appeal upheld. conviction for rape replaced by conviction for indecent assault. conviction of life imprisonment replaced with sentence of 6 years' imprisonment.

Judges: G Webster J and R Tolmay J
Summary: criminal law. review. automatic review. duty of magistrate to explain rights to accused. accused chose to conduct own defence and pleaded guilty. magistrate failed to comply with s 35 (3) of the constitution. did not determine why no legal representation and explain rights. further failure to ascertain whether cellular phones were stolen property and what led arresting officer to suspect stolen property. conviction cannot stand, not in accordance with justice.

Judges: AJ Bam AJ and A Hassim AJ
Summary: criminal law. appeal. against conviction. rape. totality of evidence indicates state has proved case beyond reasonable doubt. sufficient corroboration for evidence of complainant that was raped and appellant the rapist. no room for finding appellant's version to be reasonably possibly true. appeal against conviction dismissed.

Judges: FHD Van Oosten J and NS Masango AJ
Summary: criminal law. evidence. of identification. assessment of. evidence of identification always to be evaluated with caution. single witness. not reliable identification. appeal upheld, conviction and sentence set aside.

Judges: Phatudi J
Summary: criminal law. appeal. leave to appeal. application for. where leave to appeal already refused. court not having authority to entertain such application. struck from roll.

Judges: PD Moseamo AJ and WRC Prinsloo J
Summary: criminal law. housebreaking with intent to steal and theft. sentence. lengthy term of imprisonment. appellants sentenced to 15 years' imprisonment. although offence serious and prevalent in division, court overemphasised the seriousness of the offence. court did not pay due regard to punishment. material misdirection. appeal upheld, sentence substituted with 8 years' imprisonment.

Judges: Baqwa J and Khumalo J
Summary: criminal law. sentence. prescribed sentences. minimum sentence. imposition of in terms of criminal law amendment act 105 of 1997 for rape of a minor. substantial and compelling circumstances. court considered 38 month wait in prison pending outcome of trial and fact that complainant showed no residual effects as mitigating factors. sentence is not shockingly harsh and inappropriate. sentence set aside and replaced with 6 years' imprisonment on kidnapping conviction and 23 years' on rape conviction, name of appellant to be registered in national register of sexual offences.

Judges: RG Tolmay J and C Pretorius J
Summary: criminal law. review. special review in terms of s 304(4) of the criminal procedure act 51 of 1977. state proceeded with sentence proceedings without proving previous convictions. trial court then cannot take into account previous convictions. accused to be dealt with as first offender. magistrate erred. sentence set aside, replaced with 6 months imprisonment, wholly suspended.

Defendant: Nkosi 2014 JDR 0064 (GNP) \'97 Now reported at 2014 (2) SACR 212 (GP)
Judges: NV Khumalo J and VV Tlhapi J concurring
Summary: criminal law. sentence. fine. ability of accused to pay fine. magistrate knowingly imposed imprisonment sentence with option of fine knowing accused would not be able to afford to pay fine. not offered genuine alternative to imprisonment. right to just and fair process of the law, and entitled to be released from cruel and unusual punishment. court overemphasised on retributive theory. injudicious exercise of discretion and gross irregularity. set aside and substituted.

Judges: K. Manamela AJ and TM Makgoka J
Summary: criminal law. evidence. assessment of. court a quo rejected appellant's version as being lies and improbable. no causal link between impugned cattle and cattle auction by appellant. state witnesses were unable to sufficiently identify branding on cattle, which fatal to state's case, conviction unsustainable as failed to prove guilt beyond reasonable doubt. court misdirected itself by rejecting evidence of appellant as improbable and lies. appeal succeeds.

Defendant: Nkosi 2011 JDR 0469 (GNP) \'97 Now reported at 2012 (1) SACR 87 (GNP)
Judges: Makgoka J
Summary: criminal law. theft. attempted theft. what constitutes. where appellant's light utility vehicle found stuck in mud near cattle tied to post, and appellant himself also at scene. whether trail court correctly convicted appellants of theft as opposed to attempted theft. case law discussed. case falling into category where completion of unlawful act prevented by intervention of outside agency. appellant's conduct amounting to acts of execution or consummation of offence, constituting attempt. conviction set aside and replaced with 1 of attempted theft.

Judges: LM Molopa-Sethosa J and TA Maumela J
Summary: criminal law. evidence. adequacy of proof. onus of proof on state. whether version of accused to be rejected. accused gave explanation, onus not to convince court of truth of explanation. suffices if explanation is reasonably possibly true. not inconceivable accused version is true, must be given benefit of doubt. accused acquitted.

Judges: Dewrance AJ
Summary: criminal law. bail. appeal against refusal of \'97evidence. new evidence. produced lease agreement as proof of residence in order to be released. lease does not have essentialia of a normal lease agreement. sham agreement. onus not discharge, should be released on bail and in interests of justice. appeal dismissed.

Judges: Webster J and R Tolmay J
Summary: criminal law. review. automatic review. accused convicted of theft of telkom cables and being in possession of car breaking implements. no evidence provided to prove cables property of telkom. no evidence led on how tools found in accused possession can be used to commit housebreaking or break open a motor vehicle. not duty on court to speculate or conjecture on how tools could be used. duty on state. convictions and sentence set aside.

Judges: Khumalo J and Mushasha AJ
Summary: criminal law. evidence. witnesses. calling, examination and refutation of. material differences between witness's evidence and prior statement. duty of trier of fact to weigh up and assess all contradictions, discrepanicies and other defects. appellant failed to prove material misdirection. appeal dismissed.

Judges: Kollapen J, WRC Prinsloo J and AP Ledwaba J
Summary: criminal law. murder and rape. evidence to sustain charges. admitting to sexual intercourse and assaulting deceased on night in question. appellant observed holding onto deceased who was pleading to be let go. appellant's version correctly rejected. irresistible inference appellant raped and murdered deceased. conviction confirmed. court a quo correctly concluding no substantial and compelling circumstances. sentences of life imprisonment and 12 years confirmed.

Judges: Alberts AJ and Rabie J
Summary: criminal law. evidence. of identification. assessment of. robbery with aggravating circumstances, kidnapping and unlawful possession of firearm. complainant robbed at gunpoint in home. effectively single witness regarding identity. poor eyesight a factor. identification of appellant in police van akin to dock identification. contradictions regarding clothing worn and circumstances of arrest. insufficient corroboration for identification. reasonable doubt. convictions and sentences set aside.

Judges: Hughes J
Summary: criminal law. evidence. circumstantial evidence. assessment of. inferential reasoning. appellant's firearm murder weapon. found under mattress of appellant and girlfriend. only appellant and girlfriend had access to room except for fateful day. gave key to neighbour. appellant's vehicle used as getaway vehicle during murder. loaned vehicle to friend. appellant identified as person at scene. no other conclusion that 1 of perpetrators. sentence not shocking and inappropriate. appeal against conviction and sentence refused.

Judges: Teffo J and C Pretorius J
Summary: criminal law. sentence. prescribed sentences. minimum sentence. imposition of in terms of criminal law amendment act 105 of 1997. 'substantial and compelling circumstances'. appellant second offender for purposes of s 51(2)(a) and 20 years' imprisonment applicable, if no substantial and compelling circumstances present. court a quo correctly found substantial and compelling circumstances, resulting in 15 years imprisonment. appeal dismissed.

Judges: DS Fourie J and FG Preller J
Summary: criminal law. evidence. circumstantial evidence. assessment of. inferential reasoning. appellant found wearing bloodstained shoe and jacket, blood of deceased. co.accused also had blood on his clothes. circumstantial evidence does not justify inference that appellant murdered deceased as only reasonable one. reasonably possible co.accused was also present when deceased stabbed. this possibility cannot be excluded. for this reason, appeal succeeds.

Judges: De Vos J and Naidoo AJ
Summary: criminal law. robbery with aggravating circumstances. appeal against conviction and sentence. both appeals dismissed. appellant used an unlicensed firearm, loaded with ammunition when executing the robbery. the very next day he was arrested not far from the scene of the robbery with the firearm on him. robbery sentence of 15 years, plus firearm sentences, confirmed.

Judges: Pretorius J and Hughes AJ
Summary: criminal law. murder and rape. evidence required to sustain charges. accused declining to testify in own defence. circumstantial and dna evidence linking appellant to charges. chain of custody regarding forensic evidence broken. circumstantial evidence insufficient to support charges. convictions and sentences set side on appeal.

Judges: Makgoka J and Ratshibvumo AJ
Summary: criminal law. evidence. to sustain charge of rape and murder. rape and murder of 13.year.old girl. appellants observed stabbing deceased. blood.stained clothing items found at their respective houses. appellant 2 admitting to sexual intercourse with deceased. conviction sound. prescribed minimum sentences applicable. court a quo not sufficiently taking into account appellant's youth, socio.economic background and role played by liquor in offences. interference warranted. sentence of life imprisonment for murder set aside and replaced with 20 years. sentence of life imprisonment for rape re appellant 2 replaced with 20 years, ordered to run concurrently with sentence for murder.

Judges: MF Kganyago AJ and Preller J
Summary: criminal law. sentence. prescribed sentences. imposition of in terms of criminal law amendment act 105 of 1997. 'substantial and compelling circumstances'. appellant was in position of trust and should have protected complainant. minimum sentence of life imprisonment imposed for rape of under 16 years old. court found substantial and compelling factors to justify a deviation. no misdirection. appeal dismissed.

Judges: S S Mphahlele J and A Van Niekerk AJ
Summary: criminal law. evidence. witnesses. credibility. single witness. cautionary rules. complainant's evidence satisfactory in all material aspects. evidence was critically analysed and with caution. corroboration found in evidence of other witnesses. correct to reject evidence of appellants as false beyond reasonable doubt. appeal against conviction dismissed.

Judges: C Pretorius J and MJ Teffo J
Summary: criminal law. evidence. of identification. identification parade. both witnesses pointed appellant out in identity parade as both saw something wrong with his ear. corroborating evidence of identification of firearm used in count 1 and same firearm found at appellant's homestead. substantial and compelling circumstances found warranting deviation from minimum sentence. sentence on counts 1 and 2 set aside, on 3 confirmed. effective sentence of 12 years' imprisonment.

Judges: TA Maumela J and Y Sidlova AJ
Summary: criminal law. sentence. concurrence of sentences. sentence meted out unduly harsh. cumulatively tallied the sentence induces sense of shock. out of proportion with offences committed and circumstances of appellant. appeal succeeds, sentences ordered to run concurrently, effective sentence of 14 years' imprisonment.

Judges: Thlapi J and Pakati AJ
Summary: criminal law. robbery. sentence. appellants convicted in regional court of robbery with aggravating circumstances. appellants sentenced to 15 years' imprisonment. appeal against sentence. trial court misdirected itself in not taking into account period spent in custody by appellants awaiting trial. trial court also misdirected itself in not finding that substantial and compelling circumstances existed. appeal upheld. sentence set aside and replaced with sentence of 8 years' imprisonment.

Judges: NB Tuchten J and C Pretorius J
Summary: criminal law. evidence. adequacy of proof. cautionary rule. children. complainant both single witness and child witness. quality of evidence not satisfactory to confirm conviction. complainant's evidence contradictory on important aspects. appeal upheld, conviction set aside.

Judges: Laka AJ
Summary: criminal law. robbery with aggravating circumstances. evidence to sustain charge of. cashier at filling station robbed at gunpoint by 2 men. forced to open till and r320 cash removed. appellant arrested shortly afterward running in direction robbers fled and in possession of r320, a firearm and hat identified by complainant. appellant not testifying. only reasonable inference that appellant 1 of robbers. appeal against conviction dismissed.

Judges: Victor J, Fourie J and Montsho AJ
Summary: criminal law. rape. sentence. raped 11.year.old step.daughter for 6 nights in a row. sentenced to 6 life terms to run concurrently. appeal. appellant's attitude reflected an approach to women, and to his step daughter in particular, that they are mere chattels to be used at his will. this was a brutal and repeated attack on an 11.year.old child who was under his care and protection. appellant showing no remorse. appeal against conviction and sentence dismissed.

Judges: K. Manamela AJ and TM Makgoka J
Summary: criminal law. sentence. prescribed sentences. imposition of in terms of criminal law amendment act 105 of 1997. 'substantial and compelling circumstances'. failure by court a quo to have regard to cumulative effect of various relevant factors (personal circumstances of accused, youth, first offender, circumstances of offence), material misdirection. appeal against sentence upheld.

Judges: Monaledi AJ and Van der Byl AJ
Summary: criminal law. evidence. to sustain charge of rape. complainant granddaughter of appellant. contending grandfather raped her after school and weekends when grandmother at church. corroborated by medical evidence and first report. evidence of appellant correctly rejected as highly improbable. prescribed minimum sentence of life imprisonment. no misdirection by magistrate. conviction and sentence confirmed.

Judges: Malindi AJ and Tlhapi J
Summary: criminal law. appeal. against conviction. rape of minor. no misdirection by court a quo. evidence was correctly summarised and appropriate weight assigned. caution was exercised where needed. guilt of appellant was established beyond reasonable doubt. appeal dismissed.

Judges: EM Kubushi J, LS De Klerk AJ and TA Maumela J
Summary: criminal law. sentence. prescribed sentences. minimum sentences. imposition of in terms of criminal law amendment act 105 of 1997. 'substantial and compelling circumstances'. court erred in finding none existed. court failed to consider whether appellant showed characteristics of person capable of being rehabilitated. young offender, first offence\'97no basis why cannot be afforded opportunity. appeal upheld, sentence reduced.

Judges: Baloyi AJ and VV Tlhapi J
Summary: criminal law. rape. sentence. 15 years for rape plus 5 years for robbery with aggravating circumstances. not ordered to run concurrently. on appeal argued that cumulative effect of sentences too severe. rape brutal and cruel with complainant being stabbed. no reason to interfere with the sentences. cumulative effect appropriate for the barbaric conduct. appeal dismissed.

Judges: Phatudi J, De Vries AJ and Lamprecht AJ
Summary: criminal law. appeal. murder, aggravated robbery and assault with intent to cause grievous bodily harm. convictions and sentences confirmed on appeal. footprint evidence and found with items belonging to victims. murder, 30 years. aggravated robbery, 15 years. assault gbh, 2 years.

Judges: RG Tolmay J and C Pretorius J
Summary: criminal law. trial. record. fire at magistrates' court. reconstruction of record not possible. proceedings set aside. matter referred back to magistrates' court to start afresh.

Defendant: Molefe 2012 JDR 0560 (GNP) \'97 Now reported at 2012 (2) SACR 574 (GNP)
Judges: Rabie J, Jordaan J
Summary: criminal law. concealment of birth. section 113(3) of general law amendment act 46 of 1935 requiring director of public prosecutions to authorise prosecution in writing. whether verbal permission complying. whether accused had disposed of body. accused lying to sister at clinic, but showing police the remains in a bucket at her house. meaning of 'disposing'. conviction set aside.

Judges: Dewrance AJ and Matojane J
Summary: criminal law. sentence. prescribed sentences. imposition of in terms of criminal law amendment act 105 of 1997. court may interfere with sentence if convinced court a quo exercised discretion improperly or unreasonably, or sentence induces sense of shock or startlingly disproportionate. accused advanced illegal immigrant status as reason court imposed minimum sentence. court a quo exercised discretion correctly. particularly aggravating was use of spear as weapon and accused impaled deceased despite already being seriously injured. appeal dismissed.

Judges: Fourie J, Victor J and Montsho AJ
Summary: criminal law. common purpose. whether appellant had actively associated in joint unlawful enterprise. murder, robbery and firearms charges. plan to rob victim of laptop. victim shot in head. doubt whether appellant did actively associate. appeal succeeding and conviction and sentence set aside.

Judges: Moseamo AJ and Kollapen J
Summary: criminal law. evidence. factual disputes. approach to determination of. where court confronted with 2 irreconcilable versions. balance weighs heavily in favour of state as to exclude reasonable doubt. sentence harsh despite murder, but youth of accused indicates possibility of rehabilitation. first appellant's appeal against life sentence succeeds, second appellant's fails and sentence confirmed.

Judges: TM Makgoka J
Summary: criminal law. bail. refusal of. appeal against.

Judges: MJ Teffo J and SAM Baqwa J
Summary: criminal law. evidence. witnesses. credibility. single witness. witness was excessively drunk when offence was committed. state relied on her evidence to convict appellants. evidence was not corroborated, contradictory and lacked clarity on certain material aspects. appellants' versions were reasonably possibly true. appeal upheld, convictions set aside.

Judges: Makgoba J and Kollapen J
Summary: criminal law. review. in what cases. trial proceedings not completed. in error brought in terms of s304 of the criminal procedure act 51 of 1977, instead s24 of the supreme court act 59 of 1959 read with rule 53 of the uniform rules. proceeded as if brought under s24, condonation not to be misconstrued as acceptance of manner which matter brought on review. no basis established for magistrate's recusal.

Judges: C Pretorius J and TJ Raulinga J
Summary: criminal law. trial. irregularity in. what constitutes. accused conducted own defence. magistrate failed to adequately explain rights, especially in regards to whether want to testify under oath. not informed his version needed to placed before court under oath. gross irregularity. conviction and sentence set aside.

Judges: NV Khumalo J and BM Baqwa J
Summary: criminal law. review. special review in terms of s 304(4) of criminal procedure act 51 of 1977. formulation of sentence. sentenced to 18 months correctional supervision, however incorrectly recorded in charge sheet as imprisonment. error by magistrate in formulation. conviction and sentence confirmed, remitted to magistrate court to correct formulation of sentence in charge sheet.

Judges: Twala AJ and Fourie J
Summary: criminal law. trial. assessors. appointment of. for purposes of trial. murder trial. section 93ter (1)(b) of magistrates' courts act 32 of 1944. provisions peremptory, judicial officer shall be assisted by assessors, unless accused requests assessors to be done away with. record indicates no assessor was needed. sufficient compliance with s93ter (1)(b). appeal dismissed.

Judges: Tolmay J and Mavundla J
Summary: criminal law. corruption. contravention of s 1(1)(b)(ii) of corruption act 94 of 1992. appeal against conviction and sentence. trial court evaluated evidence and applied cautionary rules regarding both single witnesses and police traps. there was no indication that magistrate misdirected himself. accussed was police officer who was in position of trust, which he violated. police corruption is prevailing problem in society. there existed no substantial and compelling circumstances to deviate from prescribed minimum sentence. appeal against both conviction and sentence dismissed.

Judges: D Makhoba AJ and Kollapen J
Summary: criminal law. evidence. assessment of. failure of accused to testify or lead evidence. left prima facie case to speak for itself. conduct of police officials in writing up each other's statements incorrect but not affect right to fair trial to extent entitled to acquittal. appellant chose not to explain his defence to charge. appeal dismissed.

Defendant: Mofokeng 2013 JDR 1832 (GNP) \'97 Now reported at 2014 (1) SACR 229 (GNP)
Judges: Lamprecht AJ and N JV Nieuwenhuizen AJ
Summary: criminal law. evidence. adequacy of proof. onus of proof on state. whether version of accused to be rejected. inherent probability of accuseds' versions being true. no conspiracy between state witnesses. 3 accused found in house with money bags. improbable that they there and money placed there by police to implicate. conviction stands.

Judges: Victor J
Summary: criminal law. evidence. to sustain charges of murder, robbery with aggravating circumstances and unlawful possession of firearm and ammunition. deceased a rival in taxi industry. no witnesses to incident apart from accused. accused alleging acting in self.defence. version of accused rejected not only as false but not congruent with proven facts. convicted of murder on basis of dolus eventualis and unlawful possession of firearm and ammunition. taking of motor vehicle and cell phone not consistent with robbery but to destroy evidence therefore acquitted of this charge.

Judges: DM Thulare AJ and JR Murphy J
Summary: criminal law. juvenile offenders. sentence. factors to be taken into account. sentence to be based on rehabilitation rather than deterrence. probation officer report relevant to assist judicial officer in meting out sentence that will best suit needs and interests of youth. personal circumstances, role in crime and overall conduct should be accorded appropriate consideration. judicial officer failed to apply mind, warrants interference. appeal succeeds, sentence reduced to 8 years' imprisonment.

Defendant: Modisenyane 2013 JDR 2423 (GNP) \'97 Now reported at 2014 (2) SACR 453 (GP)
Judges: E Jordaan and AJ Bam J
Summary: criminal law. review. record. incomplete record. microphone had not been working, none of evidence could be transcribed. unable to determine if proceedings in accordance with justice. no indication if unrepresented accused was given proper assistance. unable to certify in accordance with justice. duty on clerk of court to ensure proper record prepared for on review. obtain best secondary evidence. untenable for various reasons in this instance. proceedings set aside as a result.

Judges: HJ Fabricius J and DS Fourie J
Summary: criminal law. review. special review in terms of s 304(4) of criminal procedure act 51 of 1977. magistrate exceeded penal jurisdiction as dictated in trespass act 6 of 1959. sentence limited to 2 years' imprisonment. sentence of 3 years' set aside and 2 years' imprisonment imposed.

Judges: Phatudi J
Summary: criminal law. housebreaking with intent to steal and theft. sentence. magistrate findings that planned commission of offence misdirection. may have vitiated discretion in sentencing. sentence induces sense of shock. appellant has habit of committing these offences. aggravating against him. sentence of 15 years imprisonment on each count set aside and replaced with 8 years imprisonment to run concurrently

Judges: Oosthuizen AJ and Raulinga J
Summary: criminal law. trial.within.a.trial. appeal on grounds that such not allowed on admissibility of statement made. in totality of evidence, no prejudice. even disregarding disputed statement, proof beyond reasonable doubt still remaining. but non.current sentences for robbery and murder too harsh, effectively 35 years. sentence altered to 15 years imprisonment for each, to run concurrently.

Judges: DS Molefe J and HJ De Vos J
Summary: criminal law. review. bail. failure of accused on bail to appear at trial. trial court incorrect to hold enquiry under s 170 of criminal procedure act 51 of 1977. section applicable only to accused not in custody and not released on bail. accused not in custody and was released on bail. could therefore not have been found guilty in accordance with s 170(1) of cpa. conviction and sentence imposed in terms of s 170 reviewed and set aside.

Judges: TJ Kruger AJ, N.M. Mavundla J
Summary: criminal law. assault with intent to do grievous bodily harm. intent. proof of. complainant's evidence that appellant hit her with his fists and open hands and kicked her not justifying conviction of assault with intent to do grievous bodily harm. conviction and sentence of 2 years imprisonment set aside and substituted with a conviction of common assault and sentence of 1 years imprisonment.

Judges: PD Moseamo AJ and TA Maumela J
Summary: criminal law. evidence. assessment of. totality of evidence not prove guilt beyond reasonable doubt. reasonable possibility that explanation provided by appellant might be true. court misdirected itself. appeal against conviction upheld.

Judges: VRSN Nkosi AJ and EM Kubushi J
Summary: criminal law. evidence. of identification. assessment of. appellant known to complaint prior to commission of offence. identified at the scene to police. appellant's plea explanation regarding alibi differs in time with what his witnesses stated. conclusion reached only 1 in the circumstances. conviction confirmed, sentence reduced to 8 years imprisonment.

Judges: N Janse Van Nieuwenhuizen AJ and AA Louw J
Summary: criminal law. juvenile offenders. trial. review. section 16(2) of the child justice act 75 of 2008. age recorded on charge sheet as 18 years of age, trial proceeded on basis that accused an adult. plead guilty and found guilty of contravening regulation 59(8) of the national road traffic act 93 of 1966, he exceeded speed limit of 60km/h. at sentencing court informed 17 years of age. section 16 of act 75 of 2008 confers discretion on magistrate to refer proceedings to high court, if of opinion error regarding age has prejudiced child. matter remitted to court a quo, conviction set aside.

Judges: AML Phatudi J and MNS Sithole AJ
Summary: criminal law. evidence. complainant single witness. rape. on appeal against conviction and sentence. complainant's evidence riddled with material contradictions. trial court holding these to be immaterial because of complainant's low untested iq. conviction and sentence set aside.

Judges: DS Fourie J and J Hiemstra AJ
Summary: criminal law. appeal. against sentence only. murder. life imprisonment. convicted on circumstantial evidence. court drew inference from evidence that murder was planned or premeditated. no proof beyond reasonable doubt. court misdirected itself to sentence in terms of s 51(1) of the criminal law amendment act 105 of 1997. section 51(2) of the act applicable. no substantial and compelling circumstances found. maximum sentence of 20 years imposed.

Judges: Pretorius J and RG Tolmay J
Summary: criminal law. review. automatic review. in what cases. sentences of fines imposed with alternative sentences of imprisonment. fines has to be such that reasonably possible to pay, otherwise purpose defeated. emphasis on seriousness of crime and not consider mitigation circumstances adequately. accused not by means to pay fine. sentence too harsh. sentences set aside and replaced.

Judges: Makhubele AJ and Bam J
Summary: criminal law. rape. sentence. life imprisonment. minimum sentence in terms of criminal law amendment act 105 of 1997. 'substantial and compelling circumstances'. only considered whether hiv positive constituted substantial and compelling circumstances. did not consider circumstances under which offences committed \'96 constitutes misdirection. sentence reduced to 12 years' imprisonment.

Judges: Ratshibvumo AJ and T.M. Makgoka J
Summary: criminal law. kidnapping and theft. appeal against conviction only. complainant forced from taxi by appellant and kept at his home over night. lost her groceries that were left in taxi and cash taken from her handbag. reported incident to police as soon as left house and returned with them to arrest him. appellant denying charges. finding that complainant credible not misplaced. version of appellant correctly rejected as inherently improbable \'97appeal dismissed.

Judges: Makgoka J and AP Laka AJ
Summary: criminal law. rape. proof of. complainant mentally disabled and not testifying. dependent on single witness of young age. irresistible inference penetration took place. complainant consenting but vitiated by medical condition. conviction confirmed. appellant 46 years old first offender, gainfully employed at time of offence and father of 3 children. 9 months in custody awaiting trial. cumulative effect amounting to substantial and compelling circumstances. interference warranted. sentence replaced with 15 years' imprisonment.

Judges: Makgoka J and Teffo J
Summary: criminal law. trial. irregularity. what constitutes. duty of judicial officer to inform unrepresented accused of legal rights. failure to do so is an irregularity which vitiates the proceedings. magistrate failed to despite comments he assisted accused. trial rendered unfair, conviction and sentence set aside.

Judges: JW Louw J and Jordaan J
Summary: criminal law. conviction. accused having paid admission of guilt fine on 1 charge. confusion as to what affect this had on his second, related offence. admission of guilt deemed a conviction. irregular findings of magistrate set aside.

Judges: HJ Fabricius J and DS Fourie J
Summary: criminal law. traffic offences. driving with an excessive concentration of alcohol in the blood. contravention of s 65(2)(a) of national road traffic act 93 of 1996. sentence. previous conviction taken into consideration. over emphasised lawlessness of driving on roads. sentence disturbingly disproportionate. sentence set aside and replaced with r6000 fine or 24 months imprisonment subject to conditions.

Judges: Mavundla J
Summary: criminal law. murder. assault with intent to do grievous bodily harm. self.defence. appellant alleging that he was attacked by 2 assailants and stabbed. his actions in self.defence. evidence of witnesses and appellant examined. credibility findings on witnesses. conviction confirmed. appellant 19 years old at time of offence. sentences of 8 and 1 years confirmed.

Judges: Makgoka J and and Bam AJ
Summary: criminal law. evidence. fingerprint evidence. evidential value. alone does not constitute prima facie evidence. finger print evidence was dealt with unsatisfactorily. other evidence indicates appellant worked as casual labourer on complainant's farm. complainant unable to refute. cannot exclude possible reason why prints on vehicle. conviction and sentence on count 1 and 2 set aside.

Judges: Twala AJ and Fabriicus J
Summary: criminal law. evidence. assessment of. identification. court must look at totality of evidence and probabilities in particular case before making decision. complainant saw appellant a few times before, during and after robbery to correctly identify him. further pointed out by accused no 4 as having been involved. court did not err or misdirect itself. appeal dismissed.

Defendant: Maswanganyi 2013 JDR 2521 (GNP) \'97 Now reported at 2014 (1) SACR 622 (GP)
Judges: AJ Bam AJ and A Hassim AJ
Summary: criminal law. sentence. prescribed sentence. minimum sentences. imposition of in terms of criminal law amendment act 105 of 1997. 'substantial and compelling circumstances'. prospects of rehabilitation. young age of appellant major consideration when rehabilitation is considered. court erred in not properly considering issue of rehabilitation. conviction confirmed, appeal against sentence succeeds, substituted with 20 years' imprisonment.

Judges: TM Masipa J and B Spilg J
Summary: criminal law. appeal. against sentence. no record of sentencing proceedings in trial court. record incomplete as no indication if evidence given in mitigation of sentence. reconstructed record incomplete and cannot adjudicate the appeal. as appeal is part of fair trial and cannot be adjudicated without original record or properly reconstructed record, accused in relation to appeal against sentence cannot be given fair trial. sentence set aside and matter referred back to trial court for accused to be sentenced afresh.

Judges: Prinsloo J, Msimeki J and Phatudi J
Summary: criminal law. evidence. assessment of. identification. complainant identified appellant as man who prior to incident confronted her on way to school. appellant denying his attacker. no possibility complainant mistaken about identity. described scar on face, missing teeth, bad complexion. appellant matched this description. charge sheet not make mention of provisions of criminal law amendment act 105 of 1997. incumbent on state to specify case to be met. impose sentence on basis act does not apply. conviction confirmed, sentence reduced to 15 years' imprisonment.

Judges: Janse Van Nieuwenhuizen AJ, HJ De Vos and EM Kubushi J
Summary: criminal law. rape. sentence. life imprisonment. minimum sentence in terms of criminal law amendment act 105 of 1997. 'substantial and compelling circumstances'. failure of state and court to signal intent to rely on life as minimum sentence. question of whether sufficiently informed of provisions of act has bearing on fairness of proceedings, not factor when determining substantial and compelling circumstances. appellant was legally represented, and participated fully in defence through legal representative. fair trial, nothing in record indicates would have conducted defence differently if aware of provisions at earlier stage. appeal dismissed.

Judges: Tuchten J and SP Mothe J
Summary: criminal law. sentence. review. magistrate realising after sentencing that suspended sentence exceeding jurisdiction. high court setting aside sentence and remitting matter back to magistrate to pass sentence afresh.

Judges: Bofilatos AJ and Raulinga J
Summary: criminal law. sentence. prescribed sentences. imposition of in terms of criminal law amendment act 105 of 1997. imposition of maximum allowable sentence. charged on single count of rape. court incorrectly applied sentencing provisions provided for in s51(1) read with offences in part 1 of sch 2 of the act. appeal succeeds, sentence of 18 years' set aside and replaced with 15 years' imprisonment.

Judges: DS Molefe AJ, VV Tlhapi J and ME Kubushi J
Summary: criminal law. sentence. appeal. kidnapping and rape. 10 years for kidnapping and life imprisonment on each of 2 counts of rape. appellant not informed of applicability of minimum sentencing provisions and not legally represented. material misdirection. sentences replaced with 3 years for kidnapping and 15 years on each count of rape, all sentence to run concurrently.

Judges: Makgoka J and Laka AJ
Summary: criminal law. murder. alternative charges explored on appeal. appellant responding to attack by deceased and continuing to beat deceased on the ground until injuries became fatal. bounds of self.defence exceeded. more than assault with intent to do grievous bodily injury. appellant should have foreseen that the man might die. conviction altered on appeal to culpable homicide.

Judges: Van der Byl AJ and Tlhapi J
Summary: criminal law. rape. evidence to sustain charge of. complainant spent night drinking in company of friends. accused arrived next morning with liquor and invited him to accompany him to his house for something to eat. once there he was locked inside, threatened with a screwdriver and knife and raped. corroborated by police officer who attended scene. appellant denying charge. findings of court a quo regarding conviction could not be faulted but seriousness of offence overemphasised when it came to sentence. appeal against conviction therefore dismissed but sentence of 15 years replaced with 10 years imprisonment.

Judges: C Pretorius J and NB Tuchten J
Summary: criminal law. evidence. witnesses. credibility. single witness. assessment of. magistrate failed to indicate dealing with single witness and necessary caution to apply. state failed to call boyfriend of complainant and doctor who compiled j88. evaluation of evidence wrong and misdirected when finding state proved case beyond reasonable doubt. appeal upheld.

Judges: Potterill J and C Cambanis AJ
Summary: criminal law. indictment and charge. joinder of accused. accused acted in execution of common purpose. second appellant not involved in all transactions, but initiator. each individual had certain role to play in completing common purpose. prejudice to state far outweighs prejudice to appellants. appellants correctly joined. appeal dismissed.

Judges: Janse Van Nieuwenhuizen AJ and Kubushi J
Summary: criminal law. attempted murder. negligent use of firearm in terms of s 120(3)(a) of firearms control act 60 of 2000. to sustain charges of. appeal. appellant, a police officer, firing warning shot to end fight. second complainant struck. versions of first and second complainants mutually destructive. state failing to prove appellant intended to kill complainants. risk in firing in close proximity to people in built.up area. reasonable police officer in same scenario would not have fire shot. convictions on 2 counts of attempted murder set aside and replaced with conviction for negligent use of firearm. sentence of 5 years imprisonment imposed of which 3 years suspended.

Judges: KLAM Manamela AJ and DS Fourie
Summary: criminal law. theft. sentence. theft of motor vehicle. appellant has 4 relevant previous convictions, correctly taken into consideration for sentencing purposes. balanced consideration given to appellant's personal circumstances, interests of community and nature and seriousness of crime. sentence imposed not shockingly inappropriate. appeal dismissed.

Judges: Mothle J
Summary: criminal law. appeal. leave to appeal. application for. prospects that another court would find differently on issue of whether confessions made freely and voluntarily and third confession's evidence reliable. accused made 3 separate confessions and convicted on third confession. evidence taken into consideration based on overwhelming corroboration by other evidence of that version of events. leave granted to full bench of high court.

Judges: Kganyago AJ and Preller J
Summary: criminal law. rape. sentence. life imprisonment. minimum sentence in terms of criminal law amendment act 105 of 1997. 'substantial and compelling circumstances'. 3 counts of rape, 1 of which was a minor aged 14 at time of rape. minimum sentence of life is applicable. counts 1 and 2 no life applicable, cannot interfere with sentence as 3 counts taken together for purpose of sentence. interference on sentence for counts 1 and 2 would have no practical effect. no substantial and compelling circumstances found. appeal dismissed.

Judges: Thulare AJ and Makgoba J
Summary: criminal law. evidence. to sustain charge of housebreaking with intent to steal and theft. single witness. circumstantial evidence. employee seeing appellant in yard of house being demolished by his employer for development. items from inside the house near him. appellant alleging sleeping in flower bed. contradictions in account of witness impacting credibility. notwithstanding certain improbabilities version of appellant reasonably possibly true. conviction and sentence set aside.

Judges: DS Molefe J and MG Phatudi AJ
Summary: criminal law. review. special review in terms of s 304(4) of criminal procedure act 51 of 1977. contravention of s 49(1)(a) of immigration act 13 of 2002. sentence imposed not competent as fine is not an amount in accordance with s 112(1)(a) of criminal procedure act 51 of 1977. sentence set aside and referred back to court a quo for magistrate to impose sentence in compliance with s 112(1)(a).

Judges: Tlhapi J and Malindi AJ
Summary: criminal law. indictment and charge. splitting of charges. duplication of convictions. rule against is aimed at fairness. avoid prejudice to accused in form of double jeopardy. state proved 2 incidents of rape, 2 convictions justified. convictions and sentence set aside and substituted with conviction of 2 counts of rape and 1 of attempted murder.

Judges: Webster J
Summary: criminal law. common purpose. 3 accused having been at house during sustained assault on deceased. no evidence as to which accused delivered which blows to deceased. blows meant to incapacitate deceased. dolus eventualis found through inflicting of fatal blow to head. murder convictions in respect of all appellants confirmed.

Judges: Ranchod J and Bam AJ
Summary: criminal law. escaping from custody. contravention of s 51(1) of criminal procedure act 51 of 1977 (cpa). section 51(1) covering act of escaping from lawful custody before arrestee lodged in prison or police cell. appeal against both conviction and sentence. according to charge.sheet appellants escaped after having been locked up. appellants incorrectly charged, should have been charged with contravening s 117 of correctional services act 111 of 1998. section 270 of cpa allowed for conviction on 1 charge to be substituted with conviction on another charge if elements of offences were essentially same. conviction on charge of s 51(1) of cpa substituted by conviction on charge of s 117 of act 111 of 1998. appeal dismissed.

Judges: NV Khumalo J and AML Phatudi
Summary: criminal law. review. special review in terms of s 304(4) of criminal procedure act 51 of 1977. magistrate imposed sentence of imprisonment in terms of s 112 (1)(a) of the act, albeit wholly suspended, which exceeded court's penal jurisdiction. section limits penal jurisdiction to no imprisonment or no fines in excess of r 3000. wholly suspended direct imprisonment as result, not allowed. sentence set aside, matter remitted for sentencing afresh.

Judges: MJ Teffo J, LM Molopa Sethosa and D Dosio AJ
Summary: criminal law. evidence. assessment of. identification. witness identifying appellant as robber. robbed vehicle was located the next day and occupants included appellant who attempted to run away, and accused 1 who was found in possession of firearm used to shoot deceased and complainants. only inference is that appellant was responsible for the robbery and shooting. appeal dismissed.

Judges: Janse Van Nieuwenhuizen AJ and HJ Fabricius J
Summary: criminal law. review. theft. attempted theft. pleaded guilty, sentenced to 3 years' imprisonment. from evidence, item never left store. to commit theft, item must be removed from control of owner. conviction and sentence set aside.

Judges: Kubushi J and Mogotsi AJ
Summary: criminal law. appeal. against sentence. offence was not pre.planned or premeditated and has no factual basis. no evidence before court to support assumption. court cognisant of complainant's age and being attacked in her house she's resided in for 30 years. justifies long sentence but not sentence of 15 years' imprisonment. sentence reduced to 9 years' imprisonment.

Judges: Naidoo AJ and De Vos J
Summary: criminal law. appeal. against convictions for kidnapping, rape and assault with intent to do grievous bodily harm. attacking ex.wife and detaining her in a cave where he committed rape. appellant's defence a bare denial and not convincing. appeal dismissed.

Defendant: Mahlatsi 2013 JDR 1686 (GNP) \'97 Now reported at 2013 (2) SACR 625 (GNP)
Judges: AA Lamprecht AJ, G Phatudi AJ and HJ De Vos J
Summary: criminal law. sentence. 3 counts of aggravated robbery and a count of kidnapping. none of sentences ordered to run concurrently, therefore getting 50 years. whether effect of this comparable to life sentence. recent law that prisoners able to apply for parole after 25 years. discussion of mafoho (sca). total effective sentence reduced to 37 years and appellant shall be considered for parole after serving 25 years.

Judges: C Pretorius J and NB Tuchten J
Summary: criminal law. arms and ammunition. unlawful possession of arms and ammunition. joint possession. proof of possession. mere knowledge not sufficient to establish intention to jointly possess firearm.

Judges: NV Khumalo J and MG Phatudi AJ
Summary: criminal law. corruption. public officer. indicated from onset money intended for bail. no evidence led as required by act that gratification was handed over. intention. failed to prove money was for purpose of bribe or corrupt activity. evidence on a whole, nothing can be inferred that appellant promised to do anything for complainant. state failed to establish requisite intention. prevention and combating of corrupt activities act 12 of 2004, s 4 (1)(a)(i)(aa).

Judges: Ebersohn AJ and H De Vos J
Summary: criminal law. review. record. no record. accused convicted of contravening s 21 (2) read with s 31 of social assistance act 13 of 2004. accused unrepresented, sentenced to 36 months imprisonment wholly suspended for 5 years. all sentences exceeding 6 months imposed by the newly appointed magistrate was to have been referred to high court for review. magistrate failed to do so. as no record and record cannot be prepared, court cannot confirm proceedings and proceedings in compliance with dictates of justice. conviction and sentence set aside.

Judges: De Klerk AJ and Ismail J
Summary: criminal law. trial. record. record incomplete. reconstruction of. portion of record could not be reconstructed. nothing turned on evidence of these witnesses. where not of material nature and did not take case further with aspects in dispute. missing evidence is not such as to cause prejudice to accused. conviction and sentence confirmed.

Defendant: Magano 2014 JDR 0720 (GNP) \'97 Now reported at 2014 (2) SACR 423 (GP)
Judges: MW Msimeki J, CP Rabie J and AML Phatudi J
Summary: criminal law. sentence. prescribed sentence. minimum sentences. imposition of in terms of criminal law amendment act 105 of 1997. 'substantial and compelling circumstances'. court failed to obtain pre.sentencing report. court had duty to request if state or defence fails to provide. also failed to consider if substantial and compelling circumstances exist. sentence reduced to 20 years' imprisonment.

Judges: C Pretorius J and TJ Raulinga J
Summary: criminal law. maintenance. failure to pay maintenance in contravention of s 31(1) of maintenance act 99 of 1998. court has duty to ascertain into financial position of accused, especially if unrepresented. court failed to hold enquiry in terms of s 40(2)(a) of the act to determine means of accused and needs of complainant. sentence set aside, r10 000 fine imposed or 3 months imprisonment.

Judges: De Vos J and Ebersohn AJ
Summary: criminal law. juvenile offenders. trial. review. section 83 of child justice act 75 of 2008. no child appearing before child justice court may waive right to legal representation. minor accused waived right to legal representation. compulsory for child to be legally represented. where waive, court must approach legal aid board to appoint representative. conviction and sentence set aside.

Judges: E Bertelsmann and HJ de Vos J
Summary: criminal law. sentence. fine. ability of accused to pay fine. fine imposed despite accused evidence unable to pay fine due. clear magistrate did not lend credence to accused's assertion. magistrate's failure to express doubts concerning accused's veracity renders proceedings unfair and prejudicial to accused. sentence set aside and substituted.

Judges: TM Makgoka J and PD Moseamo AJ
Summary: criminal law. evidence. witnesses. credibility. single witness. contradictory statements by. complainant and witness contradicted 1 another on a few material aspects which is irreconcilable. state had not established guilt beyond reasonable doubt. appeal upheld, conviction and sentence set aside.

Judges: Kubushi J
Summary: criminal law. rape. sentence. life imprisonment. no substantial and compelling circumstances present where accused caught raping three.year.old girl. appeal against sentence. accused 23 years old, pleading guilty and showing remorse. mother and father passed away when teenager, then living in shelters. previous convictions. being caught in act, had no option but to plead guilty. life sentence set aside and replaced with 18 years.

Judges: Potterill J and Van der Byl AJ
Summary: criminal law. review. special review in terms of s 304(4) of criminal procedure act 51 of 1977. both accused are children and sentenced to 5 and 3 years' correctional supervision, respectively. no conditions attached thereto. not defining conditions, proper administration of justice was negated. sentences set aside and referred back to magistrate to determine nature and extent of correctional supervision.

Judges: Tolmay J and C Pretorius J
Summary: criminal law. review. special review in terms of s 304a of criminal procedure act 51 of 1977. fraud. sentence of 3 years' imprisonment imposed. too harsh. first time offender, 30 years old, 1 minor child. half of sentence is suspended.

Judges: Bam AJ and Baqwa AJ
Summary: criminal law. robbery. sentence. prescribed sentences. minimum sentences. imposition of in terms of criminal law amendment act 105 of 1997. 'substantial and compelling circumstances'. court a quo had already taken into consideration, which circumstances were flimsy. 10 years imprisonment is not too severe. but sentencing in trial court's discretion. appeal dismissed, conviction and sentence confirmed.

Judges: Pretorius J and Truter AJ
Summary: criminal law. evidence. to sustain charges of rape and indecent assault. evidence of single complainant witness. medical evidence and testimony of mother. appellant's evidence. appeal against rape conviction succeeding, but failing against conviction of indecent assault.

Judges: Mabuse J; Webster J
Summary: criminal law. murder. robbery with aggravating circumstances. appeal against conviction and sentence. appellant alleging possible grounds for lack of intent and lack of capacity. evidence examined and these grounds not supported. appellant having been aware of what he was doing. convictions confirmed, but life sentence altered to 1 of 15 years.

Judges: H Fabricius J and D Fourie J
Summary: criminal law. jurisdiction. matter referred back and forth between district and regional court. accused entitled to a verdict and whole process irregular. the original court before which the accused pleaded, and before which this plea was accepted by the state, must impose a suitable sentence within its jurisdiction.

Judges: Ismail J and Jordaan J
Summary: criminal law. review. special review. accused charged and convicted under incorrect statute which had been repealed. conviction to be set aside as cannot be sentenced in terms of repealed act. conviction set aside, accused may be charged de novo in terms of current act.

Judges: Makgoka J, Ledwaba J and Bam AJ
Summary: criminal law. sentence. prescribed sentences. imposition of in terms of criminal law amendment act 105 of 1997. life sentence. trial court misdirected itself to conclude murder was pre.planned and accused showed no remorse. appellant handed himself in and confessed to murder. appeal upheld, sentence reduced to 20 years' imprisonment.

Judges: RG Tolmay J and C Pretorius J
Summary: criminal law. trial. record. fire at magistrates' court. reconstruction of record not possible. proceedings set aside. matter referred back to magistrates' court to start afresh.

Judges: Bam J
Summary: criminal law. sentence. rape, murder, kidnapping and attempted murder. husband hiring 3 men to rape his wife. during attack, husband mutilating and torturing wife. husband shooting dead her son. various sentences.

Judges: K Manamela AJ
Summary: criminal law. bail. refusal of. appeal against refusal of bail. failed to adduce evidence that exceptional circumstances exist which in interests of justice permit release. dna evidence linking accused to 1 of 3 crime scenes. strong likelihood appellant would commit schedule 1 offence if released. finding based on criminal history of appellant. appeal dismissed.

Judges: Makhafola J and Fourie J
Summary: criminal law. appeal. against conviction. appellant stabbed complainant in the back, causing paralysis. evidence of complainant corroborated by medical evidence. appellant raised no valid defence to justify attack. findings are in accordance with justice. sentence proportionate to offence committed. no misdirection. appeal dismissed.

Judges: Mavundla J
Summary: criminal law. general principles of liability. unlawfulness. self.defence. appeal against rejection of appellants version, that he had acted in self.defence \'97 requirements for reliance on such defence restated. in casu, appellant exceeding bounds of self.defence by shooting unarmed aggressor. appeal dismissed.

Judges: Tuchten J and Mphaga AJ
Summary: criminal law. evidence. to sustain a charge of rape. medical evidence and complainant's version against that of accused and his mother. appeal against conviction and sentence of 15 years dismissed.

Judges: Tlhapi J, Pretorius J and Bam AJ
Summary: criminal law. rape. sentence. life imprisonment. minimum sentence in terms of criminal law amendment act 105 of 1997. 'substantial and compelling circumstances'. magistrate conscious of factors to be considered with sentencing. no misdirection by trial court. aggravating outweighs what could be considered substantial and compelling. appeal dismissed.

Judges: Phatudi J
Summary: criminal law. sentencing. substantial and compelling circumstances. youth. age 21 and first offender. robbed woman of cellphone and cash. spur of the moment crime. limited violence. circumstances justifying lesser than minimum sentence. on appeal 15 year sentence reduced to 10 years.

Judges: Goodey AJ
Summary: criminal law. fraud. tax fraud. scheme created for the purpose of defrauding sars. various legal entities instrumental in inducing sars to make vat refund payments. state made out prima facie case and accused failed to testify. cumulative effect of all factors inferring the guilt of the accused. convictions confirmed. offences displayed a single intent to defraud sars on a sustained and continuous basis.

Judges: Mabuse J, Makgoba J and Mngqibisa-Thusi J
Summary: criminal law. sentence. housebreaking and murder. appeal against effective terms of 25 years for 2 accused and life for third accused. elderly woman tied up and dying of suffocation from cloth stuffed in her mouth. first 2 appellants complaining that 25 years comparable to life and third complaining that her clean record and age not considered in mitigation. when elderly and frail are the victims of crime, the courts should robustly punish the offenders. persistence with lies in face of overwhelming evidence showed a lack of remorse and that they were not prepared to rehabilitate. however, appeals succeeding in part.

Judges: Kooverjie AJ
